DEBATE.TITLE: APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 3) 1986-87

PROCTEXT.PARA: That consideration of the votes in group E be postponed until after consideration of the votes in Group F.
Department of the Special Minister of State

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank those honourable senators who have agreed to the raising of consideration of the votes in Group F above those in Group E. They have done so in deference to my personal timetable. I thank them for it.
—We are always helpful.

—I thank Senator Kilgariff. Honourable senators will recall that during the deliberations of Estimates Committee F concern was expressed by many senators-in fact, they were expressing the concern of senators and members throughout the Parliament-about the project to provide all electorate offices with IBM-PC compatible microcomputers manufactured by HRC Technologies Ltd. My primary concern is to ensure that senators and members are provided with computing equipment which is adequate for their needs, which is reliably maintained and supported and which is delivered by the end of June for members and the end of July for all senators or in accordance with the priorities determined by the respective party leaders.

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst attacks of an intemperate nature have been made on the viability of the company, I understand that recent reconstruction of the company involving its possible takeover by another firm may help relieve the question of financial viability and other problems which led to the questioning undertaken. My statement should not be taken in any way to suggest otherwise. Nevertheless, I consider it extremely important that the commitments I have given to honourable senators and to members of the House of Representatives be upheld.

The contract between the Commonwealth and HRC Technologies gives the Commonwealth the capacity to order between none and 224 microcomputers. Some 81 have already been ordered. I have instructed my Department not to place any further orders as I have received many complaints about the performance of the company, particularly in respect of meeting delivery schedules. Problems experienced include ancillary equipment not being delivered, software not being delivered until well after the equipment delivery, different keyboards from those tendered being delivered, training not being properly performed, and generally poor quality control.

I do not believe that honourable senators and members should be required to risk a continuation of that standard of service. I have therefore directed my Department, in consultation with the Department of Local Government and Administrative Services, to find a potential alternative supplier who can meet these requirements at a reasonable cost and provide an IBM-PC type unit which is compatible with the HRC equipment which has already been supplied and with the Cleveland equipment which the parliamentary departments are evaluating for use in the new Parliament House. I recognise that there are several honourable senators and some members of the House of Representatives who presently have DECmate IIs in their Parliament House offices and who have indicated a wish to have complete DECmate II compatibility in their electorate offices. I should point out however that DECmate II compatibility would only be a temporary issue since the Parliament is moving away from DEC compatible work stations to high local content IBM-PC compatibles.

TALK.START.PARA: —Isn't it a shambles!

—I am solving it. I am confident that an adequate alternative supplier can be found quickly and that, through consultation with honourable senators and members of the House of Representatives and between my Department and the parliamentary departments, acceptable solutions can be found to users' problems. I can assure honourable senators that compatible and suitable workstations will be provided to all electorate offices.

SPEECH.PARA: To give some indication of a possible alternative supplier, Mr President has informed me that the Parliament's preferred tenderer for the supply of microcomputers in the new Parliament House is the Australian firm, Computer Corporation of Australia, which manufactures a high local content IBM-PC compatible microcomputer called the Cleveland. I have asked my Department in conjunction with DOLGAS to make its own urgent evaluation of the company and the suitability of the equipment so that this matter can be quickly resolved and the delivery of equipment to electorate offices can recommence in accordance with the undertakings I have given.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Special Minister of State (Senator Tate) for his statement. It now appears that HRC-Time will supply no more machines for members of parliament and, if I understand the Minister correctly, it is likely that the Cleveland machine may end up as the preferred machine, depending upon the processes which are undertaken. The concern of members of parliament has been that we should have compatibility between the machines in Parliament House and the machines in our electorate offices. The Minister now advises us that in the new Parliament House, if things proceed as he has indicated, that will be achieved. I remind the Committee that on 6 April, when Estimates Committee F began the examination of the additional estimates for the Department of the Special Minister of State, I raised at some length the question--
—Very effectively.

—I thank my cousin. I raised at some length the question of the adequacy of the supply to members' offices of machines by HRC-Time. There were some concerns about the hardware-as to whether things like the sheet feeders were adequate for the task-some questions about the processes which were undertaken and the supply of equipment, some of those matters to which the Minister referred, and some questions as to the software.

SPEECH.PARA: I followed that up with a question to the Minister in the Parliament on 30 April, in which I raised some more specific questions on the basis that the central processing unit being supplied had on the back of it a label `Made in Taiwan' and appeared to be an Osborne machine. I asked the Minister whether that was consistent with the tender arrangements. That question now becomes really one of history. It is no longer relevant to the issues. New machines are to be supplied and I understand the Minister will be making new arrangements; there will be a new tender and new requirements. So I shall not pursue that question.

I want to raise just two matters, though. Following the first question and the first airing of this matter in the Parliament, the 4 May issue of a magazine called Computing Australia had on its front page an article headed `Taiwan gets MP's dollars'. It was a story about the supply of equipment to Parliament House offices and it quoted me, among other people. Following that, I received a telex sent by Mr David Lloyd, General Manager, HRC Technologies Ltd, which was received in the Senate on 14 May 1987 and delivered to me. This telex is being made available to my lawyers. In that telex the company says in part:

The comments made by Senators Baume and Cadman under the protection of parliamentary privilege have obviously been made without thorough research and quite amazingly without directing any inquiry whatsoever to this company.
The questions we raised were questions seeking information and, indeed, the Minister has gone to some lengths to give us that information. The telex goes on to say:
Notably Senator Baume has claimed-
and I say for my cousin's sake that it was Senator Peter Baume who claimed-
that there is a substitution racket operating with respect to the computers and that this company is under a scheme of arrangement.

As to whether a substitution racket is operating, that is a matter of history. I did not ever say there was. I framed my parliamentary question to the Minister to say that we were concerned lest that could be the case. As to whether the company is under a scheme of arrangement, I made no such comment. I am sorry that HRC Technology has seen fit to publish a statement such as that. It goes on to say that it was a cowardly thing to do and that if I had said it outside of the Parliament it would have sued me. Unfortunately, Computing Australia in its 18 May issue saw fit to repeat the allegation that I had claimed that the company was under a scheme of arrangement and that HRC Technology would have sued me. HRC Technology may well care to examine the statements it has made about what I am alleged to have said. I certainly will be seeking advice about it. I thank the Minister for what he has undertaken. I thank him for the promptitude with which he has acted and the decision which he has given to this matter. If we end up with machines in the Parliament which are compatible with the machines in our electorate offices, if we end up with software that we can use and which will work, and if we end up with hardware which will do the job, we will be well satisfied and very grateful to the Minister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —It does not pay to come to the chamber to become interested in debate. What the Special Minister of State (Senator Tate) has explained gives me considerable concern. I was not part of the Estimates Committee F investigation into this matter, but I was Chairman of the Joint Committee on Public Accounts, which was given the special responsibility of looking at computer acquisition by various parliamentary departments. From time to time snippets of information came to us, which worried us considerably, that the departments of the Parliament may be engaged in purchases without, shall we say, a proper examination of the important matters of compatibility, expense and the end results of such purchases. The view has always been taken that the Public Accounts Committee should not bring the departments of the Parliament under scrutiny. But what I have heard seems to indicate that the whole of the process of acquisition of computers for members of the Parliament should have been put before that Committee. Over the short period since it has been given responsibility it has acquired certain skills and understandings, and has had at its service a range of consultants.

SPEECH.PARA: As a senator, I was aware of what the Senate was doing. What was happening did not seem to trouble me very much because with considerable speed honourable senators were given sophisticated equipment of a high standard, the process was under control, and it was being examined step by step by the officers of the Senate. Even though it was not coming under the scrutiny of the Public Accounts Committee, the procedures that the Committee itself had put into play to examine acquisitions by departments were being exercised by Senate officers.

We discovered that competition had developed in the House of Representatives in its move to acquire certain equipment and, fortunately, it decided to follow the track that had been established by the Department of the Senate. But when it came to the acquisition of equipment for the Department of the Special Minister of State, we were alarmed to see that it was diverging from the path which had already been established by one of the departments of the Parliament. Once that track had been established there was a certain locking in, as we have found with other investigations, to a certain type of equipment. That is the problem with not examining properly what is being done. Once a purchase is made all subsequent purchases are affected by the first decision. That did not concern the Department of the Special Minister of State. It went on to acquire other types of equipment which at first glance appeared not to be compatible and which subsequently was rearranged so that it was compatible. But the compatibility was awkward, difficult and inefficient. That is the problem with compatibility. The most effective compatibility is to follow the track that has been set down; to use the same equipment. Compatibility often leads to difficulties. Even if the costs are as obvious as what has been said this morning, I would have hoped that the Minister and the Department would have abandoned what has been done and re-examine from the start, even though delays would result, the advisability of using the decisions made and expertise developed by the Senate and follow that track and provide senators with the equipment that has already been proven.

Although some steps have been taken to correct it, I am tempted to suggest that this whole process should be examined by the Auditor-General and the Public Accounts Committee, not because of any recriminations but because it is necessary to find out what went wrong. It should not have gone wrong, and if we knew why it did, although we may not benefit, other departments may benefit from the mistakes that have been made.

TALK.START.PARA: —But so much went wrong.

—I have been listening only briefly, and I was not aware of the examination of the Estimates committee but a catastrophe has emerged from that that this Parliament's reputation cannot afford. It has already laid down guidelines for the departments, but it has failed in the acquisition of equipment for the use of Parliament and honourable members. A suggestion that should be followed is that the whole matter be referred to the Public Accounts Committee for examination and report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support very much what Senator Georges has been saying. From the time honourable senators first came upon the item, we could see it was unsatisfactory. Of course, in the early stages of dealing with the Estimates, Senator Gareth Evans, I think, was in charge and, as we all know, he is the Minister for unsatisfactory evidence at Estimates committee hearings. Clearly, the problem goes deeper and even if the Minister remains a Minister for only another six or seven weeks, it is necessary to consider why the system goes wrong. Certainly, an inquiry should be held into why we got mixed up in the mess that we are in and on whose advice we ultimately made the decisions that have been made. We must then go to the next step and ask why it is that people like us get into this sort of mess. We do not give the people outside this place much confidence if we cannot look after a simple thing such as our own affairs in our own offices. The problem is that, in looking after our own affairs, we are dealing with three or four departments. There is no way in the world the system we have can work and work efficiently. Every time we do anything, we must cross from one department to another, and from one group of bureaucrats to another. We are transients in the field and are crossing one another's tracks. We are getting no satisfaction and we must do better. Let us make an effort to find out who is responsible or how it came about that Ministers were able to be coerced into making decisions that were, right from the start, clearly wrong; why those things were then covered up and why it was pretended that there was no problem when a proper examination was needed.

SPEECH.PARA: The whole business has been unsatisfactory. I commend those honourable senators who have done a certain amount of work under great difficulty to try to find out what was going on. Until now, they have been prevented from finding out anything that could avoid being disclosed and anything that could be covered up. I thank the Minister for what he has done in trying to get to the bottom of it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to echo the remarks made by preceding speakers, as I am a senator who from the very beginning has been involved with trying to get computerisation of facilities for the offices of senators and members of the House of Representatives. As the whole thing unfolded it became fairly obvious to me that we had fallen not into a new trap but into the standard trap that most small businesses fall into. It seems extraordinary that that should ever have occurred, when we clearly know how to avoid such mistakes. I think that Senator Archer really tapped the central problem, namely a confusion in relation to departments dealing with this matter. I did not agree with the initial purchase in terms of the Department of the Senate, but I must say that the scrutiny of the Department of the Senate left nothing to be desired. It proceeded in a methodical and business like way and, as Senator Georges has said, we ended up with a high quality machine. However, I have to disagree, as I do not think it should have been that machine. In fact at that time I suggested that the choice should have come down to two machines, that is, the Apple Macintosh and the IBM clone, the Cleveland. I am rather pleased to see that my suggestion of 2 1/2 years ago is finally to be accepted. It is a pity that we could not have actually taken it off the top and thus saved all that money for the inquiry.

SPEECH.PARA: Nevertheless, I think that the Department of the Senate was correct in its procedures. I think the difficulty that then occurred was that, obviously, there was very little liaison between the Department of the Senate and the Special Minister of State in relation to decisions made at that point. What I find odd is that both groups were seeking to serve the same clientele and yet thought that that clientele could be served by completely separate systems, with there being no discussions between one another, seemingly, until late in the day, and very little feeling on the part of the Special Minister of State's Department in relation to the decisions that had already been made. Ultimately I found that to be an extraordinary procedure. I agree with many of the remarks that Senator Georges made. It seems to be that it would be useful actually to find out where the thing finally went wrong to avoid further problems.

In concluding my remarks, I would like to congratulate the Special Minister of State, who I think has moved most expeditiously in this matter and to a great extent has taken control of the Department. I think it has been an exercise of a Minister actually running a department rather than a department running a Minister. I know that the Special Minister of State is a humble person, but I think this is a very good example of a Minister actually doing his job properly. I was very pleased with the statement that was made. I think that ultimately it was the only way out of the exercise. Essentially, the Special Minister of State has done what Senator Georges was urging-that is, basically, we are going to start again. That is really probably the best, the cleanest and, certainly it will end up to be, the cheapest way. I did a small exercise with regard to the costings that we had already forked out for the various systems, and I discovered that in fact we had paid twice what we would have paid had we gone into a retail store. That is not bad as an exercise for losing money, and I think that that is absolutely appalling. I hope that in the new movement we will end up with a compatible system between the electorate offices and the new Parliament House and that further developments will be done by a single group.

I really do believe that the present arrangements are utterly absurd. In checking with most of the parliaments around the world I have discovered that indeed we are unique in being the only parliament where our parliamentary office is run by one department and our electorate offices are run by a separate department. I think that this suggests that a lot of money, energy and time of the bureaucrats could be saved by having one group to deal with this issue because, after all, we are doing the same job whether we are operating here or in our electorate offices.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to draw to the attention of the Committee the report of Estimates Committee A to the Senate of May 1987. That report also adverts to this matter. Under the heading `Senate Information Systems' reference is made to the process which has been followed, and it observes that in its report of October 1985 the Committee-which I think is the Estimates Committee-warned that unless there was a co-ordinated approach to the supply of equipment to Parliament House and electorate offices there would be a multiplicity of incompatible systems operating by the time the new Parliament House was occupied. From the very beginning the Department of the Senate has been sensitive to the problem. It went down a particular road and it drew to people's attention the dangers of not providing compatible software. The whole exercise is an example of what can go wrong. It is a useful illustration of the way we should not proceed. I wish to support the remarks of Senator Macklin, who pointed out that now at least we seem to be proceeding towards the supply of the same equipment in both places-in the new Parliament House and in the electorate offices. When that is done we will have what we should have had from the very beginning.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been involved in this issue almost since its beginning. I was present at the Estimates committee meeting and prior to that I was, and still am, on the Senate Standing Committee on Appropriations and Staffing. That Committee has been kept informed by Senate officers over a long period about this question of computers and information systems for members of the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: From recollection-I do not have the documents with me-in the Estimates Committee I asked officers from the Department of the Special Minister of State about the trials that they had given to their particular equipment. They indicated that there had been trials. I asked them how many senators had been given the opportunity to have these trials.

The Special Minister of State (Senator Tate) may correct me if I am wrong, but I think the response was that no senators were given any opportunity of trialling the equipment that the Minister had determined they should use. It was most extraordinary that the Department of the Special Minister of State should attempt to impose upon senators equipment which they had not been given an opportunity of trialling. We had also been advised by our officers, months or perhaps more than a year ago, that there would be problems down the track if there were not proper consultations about the purchase of equipment.

TALK.START.PARA: —They had given those warnings.

—They certainly gave those warnings quite frequently, and almost frantically towards the end. They could see what would happen. What they thought would happen has in fact happened-regrettably, at the taxpayers' expense, and to the annoyance of senators-although it is neither here nor there whether senators get annoyed. This is an impairment of the efficiency of senators on behalf of their constituents. It is a matter of great concern which raises this very important question: Should the Department of the Special Minister of State be involved in anything to do with members of the Parliament? That really raises the question of whether the efficiency and effectiveness of members of the Parliament should be at the whim, or at the decision at least, of the executive government. That is the real issue. It will have to be faced by this and the other chamber in the consideration of certain proposals around the place for the appointment of a parliamentary generalissimo. Particularly in relation to this issue, we need to be considering our constitutional responsibilities as a parliament and as parliamentarians to determine how best we can undertake our tasks on behalf of those who elected us and not have them determined by a department of the executive government. That is the issue. I urge the Senate and the House of Representatives to consider seriously at this time whether a department of the executive government should have any responsibility at all when it comes to the rights, entitlements and duties of members of parliament. This is the opportunity to raise that question.
—The Minister, Senator Tate, wishes to catch an aircraft. Senator Harradine, I wonder whether you will yield the floor for a few minutes to allow him to make a brief statement.
—We are all in that position, I guess.

—I am sorry, but I mentioned at the commencement of this debate-I was grateful to the Senate for giving me leave to have debate relating to Estimates Committee F brought on prior to debate on Estimates Committee E-that I am booked on a 10.30 flight.
—Are you really?

—Yes, I am. In relation to Senator Harradine's general question, of course that requires consideration. As he says, there are moves around which will require the most earnest deliberation by senators and members in the other place about the points that he raised. The consultation which obviously will be necessary between the Senate, which is acting on behalf of the other place, too, in relation to the choice of computers for parliamentary offices of senators and members, and the Department of the Special Minister of State, at least under present arrangements, has, I believe, got off to a very good start. On the record, I thank the President, Senator Sibraa, for his convening a meeting some weeks ago which I think was fairly lively. In it one or two of us may have been a little ill-tempered. Nevertheless, we have reached a situation now where the provision of a compatible work station, computer, word processor within the parliamentary and electorate offices of senators and members can be achieved. That is a good result, even though there has been some heartache in getting there. I rose really to explain to the Senate why I have to leave.
—Senator Harradine, have you finished?
—I think I have raised the point that has to be raised.

—I wish to add one small thing to what I have already said on this matter. Mr Temporary Chairman, I recall very well an Estimates committee meeting at which you and I were trying to extract information from the Department of the Special Minister of State, and we had absolutely no success whatsoever. I believe that the problems that have arisen in the dealing between the departments is absolutely unacceptable and unrealistic. I hope that arrangements that are now in force will overcome that. Going back to those early days, I think there was still time then to have foreseen what could happen if equipment in our electorate offices and our parliamentary offices was not fully compatible. We could not get the Department of the Special Minister of State even to listen to us at that stage. We could not get it to concede that the equipment that we had had some bearing on the equipment that we needed. We could not get any concession from the Special Minister of State at the time that it was even important that the equipment should be compatible. I found it unacceptable then, I have found it unacceptable ever since, and I object very strongly to our having to deal with two departments to get equipment which has to be compatible. The only thing on which every member and every senator agreed was that the equipment we purchased had to be compatible. It was the one matter on which we could not get a concession from the Department of Special Minister of State or the Minister at that time.
—Are the departments compatible?

—Clearly the departments are as incompatible as the equipment. I trust that from now on we will be able to have this matter dealt with in a mature and sensible way. It sounds as though we are getting somewhere now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate the Special Minister of State, Senator Tate, on having so quickly after he came to this portfolio solved a mess that has, in my view, been a festering sore for some time. I hope that he, or whoever is the Minister in the next Government, will solve the other festering sore and make certain that the people who look after the Senate, the Clerk and his staff, will have line management responsibility for the services which are provided to senators. Only when these services are centralised through one department which understands and services the needs of senators and is independent of the executive government can we hope to fulfil the role of a proper House of review. I totally support Senator Harradine in this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: As a computer consultant I am reasonably pleased with the decision that has been made. I believe that eventually good systems will come out of it. However, it is unfortunate that the equipment is not necessarily fitted to the skills and needs of each of the senators concerned. The delivery of some of this equipment has meant not only what Senator Macklin has said-that is, that we have spent a larger amount of money than we should have in this area-but also that equipment has remained idle because various people, not used to computing, developed skills in this area with equipment that was probably more complex than was needed. Other people who were quite competent-I suppose as a former computer consultant I can put myself in this category-were denied those rights because of their junior position in the Senate, and the situation was made very difficult. We have to consider efficiency in the Senate and we have to look at the precedence rules. We should give people facilities on the basis of need rather than on the basis of some concept of perceived seniority. The effectiveness of this chamber depends very much on being able to extend to the fullest the intellectual and working capacity of every senator. That principle must be considered when offering these services.

I now ask a question on the Australian Federal Police which comes within Group F, which we are considering as a whole. During the Estimates Committee hearing the Australian Federal Police supplied the Committee with statistics on the number of drug seizures through the mail system. In 1985 and 1986 about 20 per cent of the seizures nationwide resulted in prosecutions. Yet in New South Wales under 6 per cent of seizures resulted in prosecutions. This particularly low figure for New South Wales seems very strange. Is the low figure for New South Wales because New South Wales operators are more devious than those who operate elsewhere in Australia, or is it because of limited follow-up resources or less time to conclude the follow-up action in that area? Can the Minister or people from the Department explain why the statistics for New South Wales are so atypical of all the statistics?

Can the Minister also explain why we have had only a 3 per cent prosecution rate in 1987? Is this because of the effectiveness of the Australian Federal Police in previous years forcing drug criminals into more impenetrable modes of operating through the mail or is it a question of the resources available for follow-up? Are cases automatically placed in the no further action category after a fixed period of time or is there any other standard which guides officers in making that kind of decision? This is extremely important. Australia is faced with a major underground crime wave, both in terms of computer crime and drugs. A lot of the money that is being spent in this area is being spent on drug detention-on trying to stop drug trading. I would be very pleased to get some response or at least an undertaking that such response will be available from the Department as soon as practicable.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is: That the votes for Group F be passed without requests.

—Unfortunately Senator Walsh is the Minister present and he is not answering questions. I will continue to put my questions on notice. We have a problem of representation. Members of the Department are here who may be able to comment on these matters or at least be able to undertake to do something in this area.
—I do not know anything about it but I will pass the question on to Senator Tate. I cannot give any answer here.

—I thank the Minister for that undertaking. I would like to deal briefly with a couple of other departments. I commend the Department of Health for getting its higher duties staff numbers down from 31 per cent to 11 per cent between July 1986 and March 1987. It is an area in which I look forward to further improvement. Staffing is one of the problems that this Government faces. I also welcome the news that oral snuff and chewing tobacco will be banned under the Trade Practices Act from 30 September 1987-at least the manufacture and import of these things. It seems a bit strange though that retailers are being given a further year in which to offload these harmful substances. Can the Minister or people from the Department-and this matter must be very much uppermost in their minds-explain why that is happening? Can we learn also whether the National Health and Medical Research Council has been able to supply scientific evidence about the harm caused by nasal stuff as well as these substances? If the evidence has been supplied, what decision has been made on that basis? It seems very strange that we should let a harmful substance continue to be sold over this period. I repeat the two questions which should be fairly easily answered. First, are we improving further the numbers of staff on higher duties? Secondly, why is there the delay of one year once a substance is banned thus letting it still permeate through the system?
—There are some pretty detailed requests. I cannot answer them and I do not think that anyone here can. I will pass them on.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to raise a few matters regarding the Department of Community Services. I hope that we get some answers before the election. TALK.START.PARA: —In Group E we have the Department of Territories which is responsible for the Parliament House Construction Authority. I have already expressed in the appropriation debate my concern at the refusal of the Minister for Territories (Mr Scholes) to provide answers to questions that were not formally placed on notice in the sense that they were prepared, but also to extend that refusal to questions which were taken on board by representatives of the Parliament House Construction Authority for which answers were promised and there appeared to be no difficulty involved at the time in providing those answers. SPEECH.PARA: It is intolerable that those questions were not answered. An assurance was given that answers would be provided. In addition, to an extent, a range of other questions were not asked at that Senate Estimates Committee hearing in order to meet the requirements of the Minister himself. The Minister said that he had somewhere else to go; he asked whether we would mind placing subsequent questions on notice. That was done, and the Minister has now reneged on his undertaking. Surely the Minister has an interest in this information coming forward because, presumably, it would assist him in his endeavours to ensure that there is no more waste and misspending on the construction of the new and permanent Parliament House and so that there is no more waste along the lines of the $200m that has been wasted. I would have thought that the Minister for Finance would have been particularly keen to ensure that this information was provided. I must say that I would very much like the Minister to provide here and now this information to which the Senate is entitled and which it was promised at the time the questions were asked. If it is not provided here now, I think the Senate has every right to demand a thorough explanation.

TALK.START.PARA: —The reply of the Minister for Territories, Mr Scholes, has already been put into the Hansard record of the Committee proceedings. Senator Michael Baume talked about waste. The plain fact is that a few honourable senators abuse Senate Estimates committees. By that I mean that they bring in pages and pages-reams-of prepared questions, usually on trivial matters, sometimes on quite puerile matters. It nevertheless requires a great deal of effort and cost to supply answers to these questions. I know that during at least one committee hearing I gave notice that the Government would have to consider whether limits should be imposed on the amount of effort and cost which would be devoted to answering what really amounted to, at best, trivial questions. Such a decision was made by Mr Scholes.
—Were the new Parliament House Construction Authority questions trivial?

—I, personally, do not know what they were; but I do know, and I think even the honourable senator knows, that there is one honourable senator who brings in reams of questions which are at best trivial and at worst puerile.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a disgrace. The Government is hiding behind the kind of rhetoric that suggests that some kinds of questions were allegedly trivial to refuse to answer a series of proper, determined questions which specifically related to this Government's incompetence in the biggest building project that has ever taken place in this national capital. It is incredible that the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) should seek to hide behind that sort of nonsensical response, saying that, because there were trivial questions, serious questions should not be answered. That, he knows, is an absolute nonsense. The Minister, in his alleged determination to cut government waste, is no doubt embarrassed that he has to make such an inane response to such a serious matter. I gather from this that the Government has no intention of providing this Senate with details of the waste involved in the new and permanent Parliament House project and has no intention of providing this Senate with the McCain report. That is all it has to do. There is no expense involved. That is all it has to do, just provide the McCain report, for example, which we were promised.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a report on the lack of cost control in the construction of the new and permanent Parliament House. We asked for details of how many major contracts-we did not want the fiddling ones-now exceed by over 25 per cent their tender price after taking into account escalations due to inflation and other matters or increased scope. I asked for that information, which is in fact an update of the information along exactly the same lines as was provided last September in the Estimates, so that the information would be honest this time instead of dishonest as it was last time, because last time it excluded 5,000 cost variations that had not been settled. I asked if the Parliament House Construction Authority, when telling us what proportion of total contracts these ones with variations of more than 25 per cent represented, would exclude those contracts from its calculations that had, in fact, not been resolved because of the existence of 5,000 outstanding claims for additional expenditure in this monumentally incompetent operation. The cover-up that is taking place now, with the connivance of the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh), is a disgrace.

It would seem to me that a refusal to provide information at this time clearly relates to an impending election. This Government, in its usual cover-up and deceptive way, is refusing to provide information that it knows will be politically embarrassing to it in the coming election. It follows a pattern of blocking, for example, the Waste Watch Committee wherever it can, refusing to provide details. The interesting thing in this case is that they were details and information-not trivial and no-one has ever pretended they are trivial; and the nonsense the Minister hides behind at the moment does not relate to these questions in any way-that did not seem to be a problem to the Authority. Hiding behind this claim means that these questions, which are not trivial and which go to the substance of the multi-millions of dollars of waste that this Government has been happy to preside over in the new Parliament House, will not be answered. Yet in the Senate Estimates Committee these questions were regarded by the officers, including the Chief Executive Officer of the Parliament House Construction Authority, as ones that merited answers, and the officers believed they could readily supply the answers and that no excessive amount of difficulty would be involved in providing the answers.

The Minister will have to do better, for the sake of his own integrity in this place, than to give us the sorts of nonsensical answers he has just given to these questions, which are now being ducked by this Government in this disgraceful cover-up.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the spirit of ecumenicalism, might I say that I agree that the money being spent on the new Parliament House is a disgrace. It is a disgraceful waste of money. I regard it as an outrage, but let us point the finger at who started the outrage. Let us go back to the time when Senator Michael Baume was a back bencher in the Fraser Government. Let us go back to the way in which, firstly, the project was dishonestly costed. Secondly, a decision was made to follow the fast track construction method, which means more or less pouring the concrete before one properly finishes the engineering plans, causing the building to be overdesigned to be on the safe side and a whole series of errors to be made, which adds enormously to the cost. Finally, just for the icing on the cake of John Howard, Esq., M. Baume, Esq. and M. Fraser, Esq., the management system rewarded the project managers, effectively, for inefficiency, a variant of cost-plus.
—And what have you done about it?

—What have we done about it? It was too late; it had been going on for years and dozens of contracts had been signed. Some 12 months ago I personally went through this and found that little could be saved from the project by doing anything other than walking right away from it and leaving it as a sort of acropolis or parthenon of the south. I will see Mr Scholes about having the McCain report released and find out what he intends to do about it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a great pity that the Department of Territories has failed to answer most of the questions submitted to it on the understanding that it would do so. The Minister for Territories (Mr Scholes) has, I believe, shown total contempt for Parliament. The Department was one of the first to go to the Advance to the Minister for Finance, as early as last December, which proves that it probably did not have its expenditure in order. When the Department is not keeping close tabs on its expenditure, it is quite reasonable to ask about that Department's priorities and how they are set. The people who have been waiting for two years for licensing for travel agents or five years for model food legislation have a right to ask whether further delays are expected. Because the Government is not willing to bring such legislation and legislation to establish a self-governing body in the Australian Capital Territory into the Senate to give the people of Canberra a proper say in what they are doing, it is important that I take the responsibility of asking the right questions in the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: The taxi industry would like to know how much longer it will have to wait for its new ordinance and how many Government undertakings will be broken in that process. A lot of people are interested in when the noise control ordinance will be available and when the ancient, unworkable trading hours ordinance will be overhauled. These matters should be straightforward. They are not trivial; they are very important to individual Australians, to the people of Canberra. The main reason they have not been answered, and I support Senator Michael Baume in this, is that the information would be far too embarrassing in an election year.

How a department could have estimated that it would spend $10,000 on answering such simple questions is quite beyond me. I have had the experience of the Department estimating a cost of $9,000 for answering questions about trips to the islands by various officers. When that was analysed, it was found that the bulk of the money was spent sending information up and down within the Department, removing information and editing it. When it arrived, it was full of errors because so many people had edited it. The Minister himself had to send it back, and he had to send it back again when I complained about the results.

The whole performance of the Department has been unreasonable. It is important that this chamber scrutinise what is happening in the Public Service. It is its duty to do so, and honourable senators are not being given the information to be able to carry out those responsibilities. Obviously either problems occur with records in the Department or the Minister is simply being obstinate and is showing contempt for the Senate. I can see that he might well be annoyed with the Senate because it has not allowed him to get away with some of the more unreasonable proposals he has put to it. I will take an example outside of my own questions to illustrate the point. In a written answer, Senator Reid was told:

Because drafting of answers occurs in different action-areas, until February 1986, the Department did not keep records of the resources devoted to providing these answers. Since then, action-areas have been recording the number of person-hours and the level of officers involved in answering questions on notice.
This is facinating. The Department starts to collect time data and stops publishing estimated costs.

Is that because the Minister changed his mind about the cost, or were people embarrassed by how much it was costing, supposedly, to answer questions? In view of the disarray within the Department, it is unfortunate that the Efficiency Scrutiny Unit has not been involved in looking at more of the activities of the Department of Territories. I would urge any new government to do that. It appears that there are many problems. During my time in this Parliament I have followed up those problems assiduously in the Estimates committees. In relation to a number of departments, I began with a number of broad brush questions. It is only with departments in relation to which I have found substantial problems that I have continued with the type of detailed questioning to which Senator Walsh seems to object and about which he and his Department should be doing something, in the interests of the people of this country. There is no reason why in the Estimates committees I should have to do the job that Senator Walsh should be doing in terms of reviewing what these departments are setting up.

I note that the Department has managed to get its late payment of accounts down a little; originally, in the latter part of last year, bills were being paid more than 60 days late on up to 18 per cent of all occasions. I believe that this is now down to 4 per cent-but can this be confirmed by the people there? I believe that there are set targets for reducing the processing of backlogs and for dealing with claims within three weeks. Will these measures be effective? I hope that the new computing equipment will be able to produce further improvements in this area and enable the Department to capture important information which will thus make it more able to answer the general questions that are normally asked in relation to this area. I believe that the next step needed is to get a senior management team within the Department to take an interest in the sort of information flows that exist within the Department and to take early action when problems emerge.

I want to refer to three problem areas; these relate to matters that are really important to the people of the Australian Capital Territory. I refer first to the matter of the administration of leases. This is one of the areas that perhaps Senator Walsh thinks is trivial, but on which thousands, if not hundreds of thousands, of dollars are being wasted and squandered because of insufficient control and very strange procedures. The Department of Territories has shamefully neglected its responsibilities in this area. For instance, the residents of Torrens Street, Braddon, have been fighting for 10 years to get some action in relation to businesses straying from their lease purpose clauses. On several occasions residents have had to go to the Ombudsman-again, that is another cost to the public. They have had to badger the Department, and they have collected evidence in the streets, and all the rest of it. Yet, very often the Department either did not want to know or neglected to make use of any of the available evidence, as it fumbled about in relation to these matters.

We have also had the National Capital Development Commission ignoring its planning for inner Canberra by already allowing office and retail development well beyond what was expected to occur 20 years hence. When these failures have been challenged by residents and groups, such as the Conservation Council of the South East Region and Canberra, the NCDC and the Department have used their financial muscle in the courts, using taxpayers' money to hit at the individual, to hit at the people who pay that tax. They have made it clear that they will appeal against adverse decisions that are made and hope that no-one has the temerity or the money to keep on fighting. This is certainly not the way to run the Australian Capital Territory. I call for a full judicial inquiry into land planning and lease administration before the system falls further into disrepute. The people of the Australian Capital Territory have a right to know what the planning rules really are and what their costs will be as a result of the helter-skelter approach to development in Civic. These matters should be sorted out now so that people have an effective system which can be handed over very quickly to a new self-governing body which I hope any new government will introduce fairly quickly so that the Department will no longer be able to continue its procedures without any type of public accountability. Basically the last link of public accountability was when this senator or others asked questions at Estimates committees, and that has now been cut off by the Minister. It is isolationism and dictatorship; it is not the process of democracy.

Another problem which surfaced during the committee hearings was the attitude towards firefighters. We all know about the problems. I have a letter from the previous Minister who wrote to firefighters after appointing Commissioner Kerr. I quote from the letter:
The panel did not believe that any of the local applicants were suitable for appointment as Commissioner, but did recommend one for appointment as Deputy Commissioner.

I am taking action to create the position of Deputy Commissioner to be filled from within the Brigade. I believe that this will strengthen senior management of the Brigade and provide greater opportunity for a career structure.

That was Mr Uren's undertaking in October 1984. We now find Mr Scholes and his Department telling the firefighters that none of them is capable of being deputy commissioner. This breaks a written undertaking provided just before the last election. I think that the people of Canberra need to be reminded of that just before this election. It is the latest in a series of promises made to the firefighters and subsequently discarded. This type of behaviour is at the root of the lack of trust within the Australian Capital Territory Fire Brigade. Every time an episode such as this occurs we have more problems and the old grudges and scores come out to harden even further. Commissioner Kerr has certainly put a lot of effort into replacing obsolete equipment and in encouraging people to do various training courses. This is certainly a refreshing change from the bad old days. However, some of the recommendations of the committee of inquiry are being set aside in a way which will cause further friction in the long run. In Estimates committee we were asking questions about the way this was developing. We were trying to do something about public accountability, but we were denied the opportunity.

An industrial liaison and disputes committee for the fire brigade appears to be some way off. We are not told when the brigade is expected to have a `stand alone' industrial relations capacity so that the Department will stop this type of interfering. It seems that the whole industrial scene in the Australian Capital Territory will flare up, with problems with the doctors as well, because of mismanagement and because there does not appear to be any interrelation between the Department and any accountability. We are not being told what action has been taken to improve the way in which responses are made to reports submitted by fire station officers. We have no information on how quickly there will be a corporate plan for the fire brigade with functional duty statements for firefighters and an administrative manual which deals with 1980s problems. We have asked for some details on this. Does the Government believe that its silence will lift the morale within the brigade? Will it provide the people of Canberra with a more effective service for fighting fires? Will we get any information on these matters before the next election? Unless we do, we can only assume that the Government is totally bankrupt of policies associated with the Territories. Does the Minister have any intention of getting answers to these questions or will we, like Senator Michael Baume, find that we are left with a continuing scandal of waste and lack of public accountability?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some comments made by the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) simply cannot go unchallenged. He talked absolute nonsense about the cost factor. If he were honest, he would admit that although a large amount of the cost of the new and permanent Parliament House resulted from decisions taken by the Fraser Government-and all of us would recognise that-under this Administration, with the Minister for Finance supposed to be restraining government expenditure and in control of waste, there has been a minimum of $200m in evident waste on top of the hundreds of millions of dollars of increased costs for the new and permanent Parliament House resulting from his Government's decision to increase the number of parliamentarians. For him to talk that arrant nonsense is another attempt by him to mislead this Parliament about his monumental failure in controlling the cost blow-out of the new Parliament House.

SPEECH.PARA: I thank the Minister for his promised endeavours to see whether he can get from his, so far, totally unco-operative colleague the McCain report. I also point out to him that in the Senate Estimates Committee I had asked that the Parliament House Construction Authority might also state, alongside the McCain report's recommendations, just what it had achieved in terms of implementing them and why there are still 5,000 unsatisfied claims for extra payment over a whole range of contracts. Instead of the new Parliament House costing a total of $800m, even after taking into account the extra expense of increasing its size after construction had begun, it is a clear measure of the incompetence of the Minister for Finance that the bill is now $1,000m.

I should mention for the benefit of Senator Vigor that the guillotine that has been imposed on us, with the agreement of the Australian Democrats, has limited our capacity to punish this Government by pursuing this matter for as long as possible and delaying the processes of the Senate until this Government comes clean. Had there been no guillotine, we could have, as is our duty, pursued this Government on the basis of its disgraceful cover-up of this matter. I regret that Senator Vigor's colleagues-not him-voted to prevent this Senate properly pursuing these matters, and pursuing them to the death.

Now I raise another matter, particularly as Senator Walsh is in the chamber. That relates to his total misrepresentation yesterday of my concern about his Government's deliberate refusal to act in a responsible manner to resolve the Australian Capital Territory doctors' dispute. I refer now to the Australian Capital Territory Health Authority, which is a party to this. This Government, of which Senator Walsh is the Finance Minister, has agreed to offer visiting medical officers of the Department of Veterans' Affairs a pay deal which would equal-according to most estimates, it would be greater-the value of the pay deal for which the doctors in the Australian Capital Territory have asked as an interim measure. In other words, the Government is offering to Veterans' Affairs doctors a pay deal which is greater than the offer from Canberra doctors which it has refused to consider. The Minister is a phoney if he maintains that somehow I am recommending some disgraceful acceptance of some enormous ambit claim by doctors. That is totally false, and the Minister knows it.

For the Minister's benefit, I draw his attention to an article in the Canberra Times this morning. If he is more interested in chatting to the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) about his election strategy, that is up to him. He has an order of priorities. He will need to have many talks about an election strategy, because he will be desperately in need of something to help this tattered Government, this disreputable Government-this dishonourable Government-in this matter. If he is interested in what Mr Bissett said this morning, he will see that Mr Bissett has agreed that a settlement along the lines of the Veterans' Affairs deal may be the basis on which settlement of this dispute could proceed. As I understood that Canberra Times article-which I do not have in front of me, unfortunately-Mr Bissett was saying that that could be the basis. That is an absolute disgrace. Why did that not happen before? Why has this dispute gone on and on when the Government is now saying that it may well settle the matter at the level of the doctors' interim request, which the Government rejected out of hand?

I mentioned double standards. One wonders whether there are any standards whatsoever, given the corruption by the Minister for Finance of the position that I had put when I was expressing my concern for the people of the Australian Capital Territory. I was not making any special plea for the doctors' ambit claim. That is up to them. At no stage have I recommended or spoken against the ambit claim. What I mentioned, of course, was that their ambit claim would cost about $7.5m and is for less than the cost of applying to the Australian Capital Territory the Macken judgment, which was an arbitrated judgment in New South Wales. I remind the Senate that the Macken claim was the result of the intervention into this area of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). His Press release announced the appointment of Macken to arbitrate. As the result did not suit the Prime Minister or the Minister for Finance, they are now blackguarding Canberra doctors for claiming even less than what the arbitrator decided would be appropriate in New South Wales, which decision was announced by the Prime Minister as a great victory.

As I said yesterday, there are some technical differences in the manner in which Canberra doctors wish to receive payment. They would prefer a fee for service rather than a sessional payment. Those matters are of substance to them, but for the purposes of the Senate and the people of the Australian Capital Territory it is a question of how much money will be involved. This is of the essence. Estimates of the cost of the Australian Capital Territory doctors' interim request range from $6.3m to $6.9m, but the request was rejected out of hand by this extraordinary, double standards Government. Yet, as I said, application of the Veterans' Affairs deal-the offer made by this Government to VMOs at repatriation hospitals in New South Wales-would equal $6.9m if applied to Canberra.

It is intriguing, as I have said, to see in this morning's Canberra Times evidence from Mr Bissett that this repatriation system may well be the basis on which settlement of this matter could take place. I ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate: What sudden burst of inspiration has encouraged the Government to start considering this now as a possible basis when for all this time it has been spending its hours blackguarding the doctors, refusing to consider their interim request of a 6.9 per cent increase and leaving the health services in the Australian Capital Territory in tatters? Was the Government trying to play politics in the run up to the election? Was it trying to suggest that the doctors were figures to be hated, for the Australian Labor Party to gain some cheap political benefit to maintain its electoral position in the Australian Capital Territory? Or was it simply to enable Senator Walsh to talk every day in Question Time about the greedy Canberra doctors who were requesting no more-in fact, considerably less-than the arbitrator happily announced by the Prime Minister determined for doctors in New South Wales?

I remind the Committee that doctors stationed in the Australian Capital Territory who go to surrounding New South Wales hospitals are paid in New South Wales on the basis of the Macken determination. They come back to the Australian Capital Territory and are still paid on a nonsensical basis if they provide a service-which, I understand, at the moment they are providing only on an emergency basis. The Government stands totally condemned on this matter. It is now obliged to send patients to New South Wales, in some instances, where they are serviced by doctors who are paid on the Macken scale: The Government is quite happy to send Canberra patients to New South Wales where they are treated under a scale of costs which is unacceptable, according to the Government, to pay to doctors in the Australian Capital Territory. I have mentioned double standards. This is just an incredible situation. If the Government had any will, any decency, any determination to resolve this dispute, it would have done so. I can only suggest that the approach that it finds quite acceptable in its dealings with doctors through the Department of Veterans' Affairs should be adopted in the Australian Capital Territory unless there are compelling reasons against it. We have not heard any compelling reasons from this Government why the financial equivalent of the Veteran's Affairs offer should not be extended into the Australian Capital Territory. If this Government is to have any credibility in the Australian Capital Territory-which of course it does not have-in the run up to the election, I think it would be useful if it defended itself from what has clearly been a disgraceful lack of concern about the welfare of the people of the Australian Capital Territory while it is playing a particularly vulgar form of politics.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I follow up the industrial relations point that was made by Senator Michael Baume. One of the most disturbing features of the Department of Territories not having answered questions-the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) has still not answered any questions-is that we do not have the ability to probe the industrial relations weaknesses in the Australian Capital Territory and the Department which are costing the Australian Capital Territory tens of thousands of dollars. This problem may spread and cause problems outside the Australian Capital Territory. The doctors dispute is only one dispute. It would be quite useful to know how many of the industrial relations staff in the Department have formal qualifications or direct familiarity with matters such as firefighting, transport, medical areas or garbage collection issues which seem to have been areas which have caused a lot of discomfort to the people of Canberra--
—You've got a lot of expertise in that, garbage collection.

—If these are the answers to questions the Government gives us, that is what we end up with. When the Trades and Labour Council of the Australian Capital Territory makes scathing criticisms of the failures of the Department to consult over major staffing matters, there are huge problems. The Auditor- General has been fairly scathing about the financial statement of the ACTION bus service and the delays and sloppiness involved. The Auditor-General's Office expressed concern that `some of the unsatisfactory matters identified in its 1985-86 report had been previously referred to the Department, notwithstanding departmental advice of proposed remedial measures'. It seems quite unreasonable that the Department should still not have answered some questions. We are not being told what has been done to clear up the continuing problems which appear to exist in the Department since these audit comments were made.

SPEECH.PARA: We are also not being told what effect the explosion of commercial building activity in the Civic area has had on forward purchases of buses or maintenance of the aging fleet of the ACTION bus service. These are matters of considerable importance to the people of Canberra but neither the Minister nor the Department seems interested in providing this type of information. Apparently, we need to do a lot more than ask sensible and reasonable questions to get anything out of this group. For a long time Tony Vinson could not get anything sensible from the Department on the implementation of his report. Can we know what will happen and what recommendations have been rejected by the Government or the Department? Which recommendations of that report have been accepted? Also, we were given no explanation of why the Department and the National Capital Development Commission take quite different views of the medium term prospects of the Australian Capital Territory building industry. Maybe that is another reason why before an election the Government does not want to have any information or figures about the slump in the building industry.

Furthermore, we have problems with a parking overspill in inner suburbs and we have no information about moving towards a parking fee trust fund. I am not surprised that the Department declined to provide information about the overseas travel of its officers. In the past these matters have been embarrassing. I hope that in the next Parliament there will be an attitude more in keeping with open government and that the Ministers of whichever party is in government will not carry on the same process of hiding information as has the Minister for Territories, Mr Scholes. The Minister should give us some undertaking about what is happening to solve the industrial problems in the Australian Capital Territory.

I move on, because I have to refer to more departments. Not only the Australian Capital Territory has industrial problems. With the good luck of the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button, being in the chamber, I ask him about the prospects of the transport industry, which comes within the area of the Estimates. Some very disturbing information has come to us about the downturn in the road transport industry. From March 1986 to March 1987 there was a 28 per cent decrease in tonnage carried. To some extent that could come from rail freight competition but that does not explain it totally. The rail freight authorities are giving privileged rates to large companies, but have increased prices to wheat growers, who are forced to use rail. This is another way of passing costs from big companies, whom the Government seems to support, to small people. Currently, a lot of information is coming to us about the overloading of containers by large companies. What is the Department of Transport doing about monitoring this type of activity on Australian National to make certain that there is not overloading of containers? There is a desperate situation, which I am sure the Minister will be aware of, with transport drivers. The road transport industry has more than 50 per cent excess capacity. High interest rates are crippling the industry. There are no reserves. Even businesses going back to 1919 are in danger of going bankrupt. The car industry and a number of industries which provide a lot of the business for long range trucking have been affected. There has been the lowest number of vehicles manufactured for 10 years and the lowest number sold for 20 years. Car prices have moved way ahead of consumer price index increases. In 1982 a person on average weekly earnings required 29 weeks of gross pay to buy a car worth $10,000. In 1986, the same person required 34 weeks of gross income to pay $15,300 for the same car. Wages have risen by 32.2 per cent since 1982; the CPI has risen by 42.2 per cent.

There seem to be real problems with the transport industry yet we are not getting any answers from the Minister. This area involves industry, commerce and transport, but the transport industry suffers whenever industry activity is decreased or whenever there is a real economic problem. This year's inflation rate is running at around 10 per cent, which is back to the 1982-83 levels when this Government came to power. If award wages rise by 4.8 per cent this year-that is, two wage rises the same as the last-real award wages this year will drop a further 5 per cent below CPI increases. There is a real problem facing the transport industry. What is the Department doing to study this matter? What is happening to solve these problems? What type of expenditure will the Government go into to enable readjustment in this particularly important industry?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —At Estimates Committee E hearings on the morning of 4 May, Senator Gietzelt read a statement from the Minister for Territories (Mr Scholes) indicating that too many questions on notice were being asked by senators and that the Minister had instructed his Department not to commit resources to answering the outstanding questions. That matter has been referred to today. At the end of the meeting the Committee discussed this matter and agreed not to pursue the answers to the outstanding questions. I am not arguing with that decision but some aspects of it need to be reviewed. I had asked questions on 2 April and 22 April and received answers to those I submitted on 2 April. We need to look at some of the areas in which there have been problems in the Department or in the Minister's area of responsibility over the year.

SPEECH.PARA: There have been problems in public hospitals, with ACTION buses, the Australian Capital Territory Fire Brigade, water and sewerage, garbage collection, motor vehicle registration, parking, road design and maintenance and maintenance of Government buildings. These are matters that Committee members quite properly wanted to inquire about, as well as associated issues such as the number of people employed and the amount of overtime being worked, generally to try to get some understanding of how the Department was coping with these problems. I assume they could not have been predicted and budgeted for in the estimates last year. So in the supplementary estimates it really is not unreasonable to try to unravel these matters. It is somewhat of a pity that the Minister takes the attitude he does. Irrelevant and puerile questions, if such there be, can be highlighted and argued about.

Many of us felt that, given the number of questions that, when asked in the past, were given the response `We will take it on notice', putting questions in writing would give us a better opportunity to get the answers at the time of the hearings and so more speedily deal with them. If we do not put questions on notice it may well be that the hearings will take a great deal longer. I agree that something needs to be done to sort out the matter and it must not be allowed to develop into a situation of confrontation or something of that nature, but the trend towards putting questions on notice arose from the fact that frequently the public servants present, quite reasonably, were not able to give immediate answers. Putting questions on notice was perceived as a way of speeding things up. The matter will need to be reviewed.

An example of the difficulties is that we did not get the 1985-86 report of the Australian Capital Territory Health Authority until Tuesday this week-and we are just about at the end of this financial year. So to be asking questions in that area really cannot be regarded as unreasonable when we think of the difficulties patients seeking attention in Canberra hospitals have experienced, just about since Medicare came in and certainly more recently. I placed 20 questions on notice, and I do not regard that as being unreasonable in the circumstances. Certainly the attitude of the Minister for Territories is quite different from that of Senator Gareth Evans, who chided Senator Durack in Estimates Committee B on 31 March when he said: `If you have not remembered to pursue the matter, that is your lookout'. It is a somewhat inconsistent attitude. If we try to look after ourselves in Estimates Committee E we are told that we will not get answers, and if we do not in Estimates Committee B we are told it is our own fault.

I think it would be difficult for anyone to suggest that a 40 per cent increase over the last two years represents any reasonable rate of inflation. This Government is maintaining its policy of covering up this scandal by refusing to give honourable senators the opportunity to discuss the efficiency audit to be brought down next week, by refusing our requests at Senate Estimates committees for information, which it promised to provide, and by not telling us the additional details and the Auditor's response to them as outlined in his report. 12.2 (1) An infant may be carried in the arms or on the lap of an adult passenger or in a bassinet providing the bassinet is restrained so as to prevent it from moving under the maximum accelerations to be expected in flight and in an emergency alighting, and precautions are taken to ensure that, at the times seat belts are required to be worn, the infant will not be thrown from the bassinet under these accelerations.

(2) When an infant is carried in the arms or on the lap of a passenger in accordance with paragraph 12.2 (1) the seat belt, when required to be worn, shall be fastened around the passenger carrying or nursing the infant, but not around the infant.

13.1-General

When sick or injured persons are carried in an aircraft, all reasonable precautions shall be taken to prevent hazards to other occupants and particular attention shall be given to the handling of such persons in emergencies.
13.2-Carriage of Stretcher Cases.
The carriage of stretcher patients in any aircraft shall be in accordance with the following requirements-

(a) The stretcher shall be secured in the aircraft so as to prevent it from moving under the maximum accelerations likely to be experienced in flight and in an emergency alighting such as a ditching; and
(b) The patient shall be secured by an approved harness to the stretcher or aircraft structure.
Note: Psychiatric restraint equipment is not an approved harness for this purpose.
13.3-Carriage of Mentally Disturbed Persons.
(1) A mentally disturbed person shall not be carried in an aircraft unless-
(a) accompanied by an escort; and
(b) a medical certificate has been issued by a medical practitioner certifying the patient's suitability for carriage by air, and whether there is a risk of violence from such a patient.
(2) Where the medical practitioner, approving the carriage of a mentally disturbed person, certifies that there is a risk of violence from such a person, the following conditions shall apply-
(a) only one mentally disturbed person shall be carried on the aircraft;
(b) the person shall be under adequate sedation throughout the flight;
(c) the person shall be accompanied by a qualified nurse (psychiatric trained where available) and one other attendant;
(d) the person shall be secured to a stretcher in accordance with the requirements of sub-paragraph 13.2;
(e) where the person is not restrained by psychiatric restraint equipment, a barrier, such as a locked door, wire screen or net, shall be provided between the person and the flight deck/cockpit; and
(f) therapeutic oxygen shall be available.
14-CARRIAGE OF HANDICAPPED PERSONS
14.1-When handicapped persons are carried in an aircraft all reasonable precautions shall be taken to prevent hazards to other occupants.
14.2-The carriage of handicapped persons in regular public transport or charter operations shall be in accordance with the following requirements-
(a) the operator shall establish procedures which will identify as far as possible passengers who are handicapped;
(b) the operator shall ensure that handicapped persons are not seated in an aircraft where they could in any way obstruct or hinder access to any emergency exit by other persons on the aircraft; and
(c) the operator shall ensure that individual briefings on emergency procedures are given in accordance with the requirements of Air Navigation Orders, Section 20.11.
