6. In relation to the property which is currently the subject of Supreme Court proceedings between the Orionia family and Orionia Israel, Dr Hempel, Mr Etheredge and Mrs Marshall were particularly upset that the department had been intending to hand over to Messrs Rahat and Yitzhak property which they claimed belonged to individual members of the Orionia family and not to Orionia Israel. They said the vessel was the home of the members of the Orionia family in addition to being a charter vessel and that consequently it had contained all their individual possessions. In many cases they had documentary proof of their ownership, yet as a consequence of the Department's actions they had been forced to institute legal proceedings for the recovery of their own property.

7. The history of the vessel as explained by Dr Hempel and Mr Etheredge and as outlined in Dr Hempel's letter of 6 April 1986 is not that of a vessel purchased by Orionia Israel as a luxury charter vessel complete with all fixtures, fittings and furnishings included in the purchase price. The vessel was purchased for the relatively small sum of #18,000 and substantial structural repairs and alterations were made by the Orionia family to enable it to be a home for the family. The vessel was then sailed to Israel by the Orionia family with all their personal belongings and ownership of the vessel was transferred to Orionia Israel. Dr Hempel claimed that in these circumstances only items that clearly belonged to the vessel should have been handed over to the duly authorised representatives of the company and that all of the property being stored by Customs belonged to members of the Orionia family and not the vessel.
Ownership of Orionia Israel

8. The major part of the meeting was spent in discussing the ownership of the company Orionia Israel. Dr Hempel agreed that the vessel was owned by Orionia Israel but claimed that this company was owned by Orionia Guernsey. Dr Hempel and Mr Etheredge laid great stress on the fact that the Decision of the Beer Sheba District Court of Israel dated 24.5.85 referred to ``the agreement between the parties which has received the validity of a Judgment''. One of the respondents listed in the decision is ``Orionia Limited Gransi'' and Dr Hempel claimed that ``Gransi'' was a mis-translation of Guernsey.

9. Dr Hempel claimed that the agreement referred to in the Decision of the Beer Sheba District Court was the agreement whereby Orionia Guernsey agreed to pay US$150,000 to a Mr David Lewis (whose company, Acorn International Hotels, had fraudulently became registered as the sole shareholder of Orionia Israel) and that Mr Lewis would transfer ownership of the shares of Orionia Israel to Orionia Guernsey. The US$150,000 for the settlement was loaned to Orionia Guernsey by five Israeli investors, two of whom were Messrs Rahat and Yitzhak.

10. It is at this point that matters become somewhat complicated and unclear. Dr Hempel maintained at the meeting that he had signed a loan agreement or agreements on behalf of Orionia Guernsey by virtue of a Power of Attorney granted by that company on 12 April 1985, a copy of which I attach herewith for your information. Dr Hempel claims that he has never been provided with a copy of this loan agreement or agreements. Furthermore, Dr Hempel says that although it was proposed that a trust (the Oak Trust) be set up for tax purposes to hold all of the shares of Orionia Israel in trust for Orionia Guernsey he is not sure whether the Trust was set up as he has never seen any documents. Nor has he seen any documents in relation to the appointment of directors of Orionia Israel although he does not deny that he may have provisionally agreed to their appointment. Dr Hempel claims that his Power of Attorney required that all acts carried out by him on behalf of Orionia Guernsey had to be ratified by the Board of the Orionia Guernsey and that as he has never been given copies of any of the documents which he signed he has not been able to forward them to Guernsey for ratification. As a result there has not been any valid appointment of Messrs Rahat, Yitzhak or Ecker as Directors of Orionia Israel and no transfer of the ownership of the company's shares to any trust company.

11. Dr Hempel also referred to a statement by Mr E. D. Ecker of Volovelsky dated 3 September 1985 setting out the composition of shareholders in Orionia Israel. He maintained that there was never any agreement or intention to transfer shares in Orionia Israel to Mali Line Ltd or to Mr Rahat. This company and Mr Rahat are the owners of 59,000 and 29,500 shares respectively in Orionia Israel. The other shareholder of Orionia Israel is stated to be AV''H Trust Company Limited with 147,500 shares. Dr Hempel is adamant that there has never been any transfer of the beneficial ownership of Orionia Israel shares which have at all times been owned by or held in trust for Orionia Guernsey. If any shares are now beneficially owned by any company or person other than Orionia Guernsey then there has been a fraud committee against Orionia Guernsey.

12. I advised Dr Hempel, Mr Etheredge and Mrs Marshall that the Department was seeking instructions from the Israeli authorities in relation to the matters raised in Dr Hempel's letter of 6 April 1986 and in relation to the representations made by Mr G. Campbell M.H.R. and Mr P. Drummond M.H.R. I further informed them that it was the Department's intention to adjourn the hearing of the extradition proceedings if further information had not been received from Israel prior to the hearing date of those proceedings. I also advised I would notify the Department of the substance of the representations which they had made at the meeting. The meeting concluded at 4.45 p.m.

13. Dr Hempel, Mr Etheredge and Mrs Marshall gave the impression of being honest, sincere persons who considered that the Orionia family had twice been the victims of fraud, firstly by Mr David Lewis and secondly by the Israeli investors who had loaned the sum of US$150,000 to Orionia Guernsey. They are greatly concerned that if the vessel is now sold at substantially less than its value (which they estimate at approximately A$800,000) they will suffer an irrecoverable loss as they simply do not have the resources which would be required to commence lengthy legal proceedings in Israel. I confirm my previous advice that the vessel has been placed on the market through Matt-Tasker Brokerage of 43 Swan Street, North Fremantle.

14. I consider that there are several aspects of this matter which require further investigation and that copies of all relevant documents should be obtained, including the agreement referred to in the Beer Sheba District Court Decision, all Israeli corporate affairs documents in relation to the appointment of directors of and shareholdings in Orionia Israel since its incorporation, the loan agreement or agreements between the five Israeli investors and Orionia Guernsey, the documents establishing the HV''A Trust Company Limited and dealing with its shareholdings, and documents relating to the setting up of the Trust and its terms. Until copies of these documents are obtained the true position of the ownership of Orionia Israel and the vessel will remain a matter of conflicting claims and counterclaims.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bills now being debated are a group of five Bills under Order of the Day No. 6 and two Bills under Order of the Day No. 7-the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1986 and the Income Tax Amendment Bill 1986. There has been earlier debate on the latter two Bills and the Opposition will pursue further debate on them in the Committee stage. I foreshadow two amendments to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1986, but that will come at the Committee stage of the debate. The main Bills for debate at the second reading stage are the Taxation Laws Amendment (Company Distributions) Bill, the Income Tax (Franking Deficit) Bill, the Income Tax Rate Amendment Bill, the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) and the Bank Account Debits Tax Amendment Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: Collectively, they comprise yet another instalment of the so-called Keating tax reforms of 1985. Collectively, but more particularly the first couple of them, they comprise what have been called the imputation Bills. In considering the legislation the Senate should remember that the package adds another 100 pages to the taxation law of this country. Other tax Bills from the tax measures of September 1985 have been introduced previously. This legislation is part of that package. Since 19 September 1985, when the Treasurer, Mr Keating, introduced his reform of the Australian taxation system, otherwise well known and appropriately known as the RATS system, an additional 831 highly complicated pages of taxation legislation have been introduced. Those pages constitute an addition of nearly 70 per cent to the total taxation law in less than two years. The general burden of all that has fallen on the community and, in particular, the business sector. On behalf of the Opposition, I move:
At end of motion, add ``, but the Senate-
(1) condemns the Hawke Labor Government for raising the company tax rate from 46 per cent to 49 per cent at a time when company tax rates around the world are being lowered;
(2) notes that the Government's so called `tax reform' proposals have imposed an additional tax burden on business in excess of $2,000 million;

(3) notes that these new business taxes have been imposed at a time when the level of business investment in this country has fallen to an appallingly low level and there is a rising tide of bankruptcies;

(4) notes with concern that the interaction of the proposals in the Taxation Laws Amendment (Company Distributions) Bill 1987 with the foreign tax credit system and the new capital gains tax imposes a tax disadvantage on companies and on their shareholders;
(5) notes that the Taxation Laws Amendment (Company Distributions) Bill 1987 also contains unnecessarily complex administrative and compliance procedures for companies, and therefore,
(6) calls upon the Government to restore the incentive to invest by pursuing a more balanced economic policy and reducing the taxation and administrative burden on business''.

I shall deal first with the Taxation Laws Amendment (Company Distributions) Bill, which is better known as the imputation legislation. From the whole package of measures brought in by the Government on 19 September 1985, we note that the overall additional burden on business is, as I said in the amendment I proposed, $2 billion. That is being imposed at a time when we are looking for business in Australia to invest in new productive enterprises. It is little wonder that a lot of takeover activity is occurring, that a lot of investment is going off-shore and that a lot of concern is being expressed about the lack of investment in any new productive enterprises in Australia when one considers the taxation regime-which has been the hallmark of this Government-that is being imposed on business. It is only through investment in new productive enterprises that jobs and the wealth to provide this nation with vitality and future growth will be created. Without that, wealth cannot be distributed to families, income cannot be created and the taxes necessary to look after the disadvantaged, the pensioners, the welfare beneficiaries and others in need in the community cannot be levied.

The Government is setting out deliberately, coldly, callously-and stupidly-to kill off the goose that lays the golden egg before the golden egg of additional income and wealth has been created. Investment in Australia is a critical factor for Australia's future prosperity. The package the Senate is looking at has some good elements and, as I said earlier, the Opposition will not oppose these imputation Bills. Nevertheless, the whole raft of anti-business taxation that has been foisted on the business community in Australia in the last four years of the Hawke Government, but more particularly since the September 1985 tax package, has mightily set back the additional investment and productivity growth that we so desperately need and which the Government says it is seeking to achieve. If that is what it is seeking to achieve, it had better look very hard at the methods it has been employing because they have been totally counterproductive.

In the whole of the package introduced by the Treasurer in 1985 only two measures could remotely be said to have promoted investment or helped the taxpayer. The first of those was the reduction in marginal rates of tax which, although insufficient, was still welcome although I must say that the impact of it on the family receiving average weekly earnings will still be negative in the sense that the December 1986 and July 1987 tax cuts will not restore the average Australian family to the tax position that it was in prior to the election of the Hawke Government in 1983. The average Australian family with young children would need an additional tax cut of $15 a week over and above the December 1986 and July 1987 tax cuts simply to be restored to the taxation position it was in prior to the election of the Hawke Government. Nevertheless, we do welcome the reduction in the marginal tax rates.

The other measure from 1985 which is welcomed in the sense that it brings taxation relief for shareholders is the imputation system, which is an important part of the Bills before us. The Opposition welcomes the tax relief to shareholders of private and public companies who pay tax. Of course in this case, those shareholders who are not liable to pay tax will get no benefit, but we do welcome the benefits for those who are liable. However, I wish to draw to the attention of the Senate some serious implications of the package. We have been told by the Government that the total cost to revenue of the imputation system and related measures is $775m but that that will be offset by increasing the company tax rate from 46 per cent to 49 per cent-so the net cost is expected to be about $50m in 1987-88 and $300m a year thereafter. In other words, while shareholders will get some welcome benefit, a considerable additional burden will be placed on companies.

Some aspects of the imputation provisions do not help companies and their shareholders. I draw attention to some of these as they are very important in the total scheme of investment and resource allocation and the best use of our resources here in Australia. The first point relates to the interaction of the foreign tax credit system, which has already been introduced by the Government with the imputation system. This interaction will prejudice those companies with substantial earnings from overseas operations. These companies will not be able to pay fully tax free dividends from this off-shore income and thus off-shore direct investment will be less desirable at a time when the Government is supposedly encouraging such investment. I am referring to those Australian multinational companies, those companies that are sufficiently energetic and innovative to establish new companies overseas, to develop new markets and to put capital overseas in relation to those markets so that we can get further growth and further earnings for Australian companies, and so that they can then repatriate profits to Australia. They are the companies that I believe we should be encouraging. We do not necessarily want to encourage off-shore investment-we want to encourage on-shore investment-but above all we want to encourage an overall pattern of investment for Australian companies that is in the best interests of this nation.

This aspect of the relationship of the foreign tax credit system with the imputation system is going to militate against those companies. As an example, if a company pays 35 per cent tax in the United Kingdom-which is the going rate-the foreign tax credit system will require an additional 14 per cent tax to be paid in Australia on profits repatriated to Australia. It is only this 14 per cent Australian tax paid amount-an amount grossed up by 51 over 49, which is the technical formula involved-that can be paid as a tax free dividend to resident Australian shareholders. The 35 per cent that has gone in the form of United Kingdom tax, again grossed up by the formula of 51 over 49, would be fully taxable in the hands of individual shareholders if paid as a dividend. So clearly the interaction of another one of the Treasurer's impositions with this benefit has a net adverse effect on companies based in Australia and operating overseas as well.

There is also a problem with the interaction with the capital gains tax. The benefit of the indexation of capital gains-which, of course, the Government has said to us is one of the major reasons why the capital gains tax is not as vicious as the Opposition, the business community and the rest of the community claim it is-under the new capital gains tax system largely will be lost, as it is not possible to pay a tax free dividend out of the indexed portion of a capital gain. For example, if an asset were purchased for $100,000 and subsequently sold for $150,000, and the consumer price index in that period had risen by 20 per cent, the sale proceeds would be $150,000 and the indexed cost would be $120,000, leaving a taxable gain of $30,000. If tax at 49 per cent is applied to that, the company would pay $14,700 in tax. The company then credits to its franking account-that is, to the dividend tax free account, with this amount to be available for payment to shareholders, as I have said, as a tax free dividend-the amount of tax, that is, $14,700 multiplied by the formula of 51 over 49, leaving $15,300.

Of course, under law, the company is able to distribute dividends based on this capital sale unrelated to the indexation provisions of the capital gains tax. In the case referred to, the proceeds in cash are $150,000, and with the cost of the asset being $100,000 that leaves $50,000 profit less the tax of $14,700, so $35,300 is available for distribution. If this full $35,300 were paid out as a dividend, only $15,300 would be tax free and the entire indexed portion of $20,000 would be fully taxed in the hands of individual shareholders. So there we have an interaction between the capital gains tax and the new imputation proposals which disadvantages companies and shareholders where there is a capital gain subject to indexation. That is yet another example, I believe, of the Government introducing a range of very complex and very interrelated taxation proposals which, because of their complexity and their volume, means almost certainly that at some time counterproductive interactions will occur between one and the other. That is what we see in this case in relation to the interaction between the imputation system and the foreign tax credit system as well as the interaction between the imputation system and the capital gains tax-and there are other instances as well where those interactions do prove to be counterproductive. I think this is a very salutary example to us all of the pitfalls that are involved in the taxation system when one adds layer after layer to it, making what is already a difficult and complex area almost unbelievably difficult and convoluted.

A third problem with the imputation system is that whilst the benefits of imputation rebates will pass through companies, trusts and partnerships with shareholders to the ultimate individuals, this will not occur for trusts which make a loss in a year. In other words, if a company or partnership is experiencing a loss, the benefit of the imputation rebate on dividends paid by the company in which shares are held will still be available, whilst for a trust shareholder experiencing a loss the imputation rebate will be entirely lost. There is no logic in this tax distinction between the two forms of potential beneficiaries. Other aspects of this Bill, including the removal of branch profits tax and dividend withholding tax, follow on automatically and sensibly from the imputation system. There are also other changes to the taxation of liquidations to which we have no objection.

I wish to say a few words on some of the other Bills, including the Income Tax (Franking Deficit) Bill 1987 which formally imposes the franking deficit tax contained within the imputation legislation. That is an automatic follow-up Bill and again we have no objection to it. The Income Tax Rates Amendment Bill 1987 is a real problem; it is a killer. This is the Bill that increases the company tax rate from 46 per cent to 49 per cent. That increase of 3 percentage points is in fact an increase of almost 7 per cent in company tax. That will put Australia still further down in the league of international competitiveness. If Australia has company tax rates which are too high relative to those of the rest of the world, then companies simply will not operate here. Companies will not be formed and people will not bother to start up a business. Therefore they will not be in a position to employ people, generate income, earn profits or pay tax and the whole country will become poorer as a result. The lifting of the company tax rate to 49 per cent puts Australia in a very high tax league. It was already very high in that league before the lift. Let me give some comparisons. Australia's corporate tax rate is now 49 per cent compared with the rate in the United Kingdom which has been lowered recently by the Thatcher Government to 35 per cent. In the United States the corporate tax rate is 34 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —But they have got rid of a lot of deductions. You can afford to lower your tax rate if you are not giving people deductions such as accelerated depreciation and so forth.

—I agree that one must look at this matter in totality, but the fact remains that the corporate tax rate in Australia is much higher than that in either the United Kingdom or the United States of America. In New Zealand, which is having considerable economic difficulties, the Labour Government there has recently increased the company tax rate to 48 per cent. That is still lower than ours. In Japan the rate is 42 per cent; in Hong Kong it is 18 per cent; and in Singapore it is 43 per cent. Some other countries have higher rates than ours. In Germany it is 56 per cent and in France it is 50 per cent. Canada with 46 per cent is about the same as we are, or at least it was the same before we increased our rate to 49 per cent. Those countries with tax rates lower than ours put their businesses in a better competitive situation relative to ours and that is something which must be seriously recognised.
—You mean there are high rates of protectionism.

—No, I was not referring to the protective side of this matter at all. If we slug our companies, productive activities and enterprises in Australia we must inevitably face the consequences of lower growth, employment, income and wealth generation than would otherwise be the case. Thus we have a lower capacity to look after the living standards of all Australians. This is a very important factor that is hitting and hurting Australian industry. A recent study has been undertaken by the well-known and respected accounting firm, Arthur Young and Co. of Sydney on behalf of various potential clients. That company-and the person involved was a Mr Peter Knox-has said that a valid comparison of relative tax advantages has been provided by the work the firm did for off-shore companies considering investing in Australia and for domestic companies investing outside Australia. The company was asked to look at the relative situation and it concluded that, from the perspective of relative tax rates, Australia is not a favourable place for off-shore investment by overseas companies. A US company investing in Australia would have to look at keeping only 51 per cent of its earnings as against about 66 per cent in the US-perhaps a little less after allowing for certain regional taxes. When companies in America can keep 66 per cent of their earnings and those in Australia can keep only 51 per cent, why on earth would they want to invest here? Similarly, an Australian company which might pay 34 per cent of its US earnings under the foreign tax credit system must top up its US taxes with an additional 15 per cent to bring them up to Australian domestic company tax rates. However, in franking dividends under imputation, the company would only be allowed to do so to the extent of the Australian tax and would not be given any credit for US tax already paid. Mr Knox, of Arthur Young and Co. concluded:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the foreign tax credit and imputation were hurting smaller, high-technology private companies which had promising markets in overseas companies.
These are the very sunrise-type industries that we are trying to promote. Then Mr Knox made a comment which we should listen to very carefully. He said:
This amounts to a tax on ingenuity.

The very thing that we want to encourage in this country is entrepreneurship, ingenuity and innovation. We want people to have the opportunity to get up and have a go. If people have new ideas we want them to get in there and develop them, to grow and prosper and therefore provide benefits, not only to themselves but also to all Australians through their enterprise and activity. The combination of the tax system and the proposals that are now before us amounts to a tax on ingenuity.

The details of individual taxation measures are very complex and difficult to follow and one cannot look at them without looking at the overall burden of taxation. The new taxes that have been levied on the business community by this Government since September 1985 amount to an additional $2,000m. In other words, the Treasurer has the extraordinary distinction of taxing businesses an extra $2 billion as well as adding to the taxes of ordinary Australians. A family on average weekly earnings with dependent children has had its average rate of taxation increased under this Government from 17 1/2 per cent to 20 1/2 per cent, even after all the tax reforms. The top marginal rate of tax for the family on average weekly earnings will have gone up from 30 per cent to 40 per cent. It is not a question of businesses being taxed more so that individuals can pay less. Under this Government, both businesses and people individually are being taxed more in order to fund the extraordinary extravagances of the Government. That is the simple, undeniable fact and it is the reason for the inexorable and enormous growth in taxation that has occurred in this country over the past four years. That total burden of taxation on any nation will weigh increasingly heavily, be it company tax, personal tax or any other form of taxation. Unless we lower the overall burden of taxation in this country we will never have the dynamic, vital, striving country that is essential for our future growth and development and for which we are so superbly placed in the world to move forward into the next century. We are placing great constraints and hobbles on our opportunity to expand and grow in a way that is nothing short of criminal.

The package of Bills also includes the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987. I would have liked to comment on other aspects of that and other legislation, but time has defeated me. The abolition of Division 7, for example, is welcome. It is a necessary follow-on from the imputation system. To summarise, we have before us from the Government another 100 pages of highly complicated legislation which will simply be an additional burden on business and another death blow to investment in this country at a time when we need the opposite. I hope very much that that will be reversed in the years ahead. It will certainly start to be reversed in six weeks when the new Liberal-National Party government takes over because, above all else, it will restore incentive, prosperity and enterprise to this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating a number of major items of legislation dealing with the taxation of company income. I want to address my remarks particularly to the Taxation Laws Amendment (Company Distributions) Bill 1987, the Income Tax (Franking Deficit) Bill 1987 and the Income Tax Rates Amendment Bill 1987. These Bills will give effect to the most significant business taxation reforms in this country since World War II and in essence will eliminate the double taxation of company dividends. It is such a major reform-the greatest since 1975 and I support the legislation. In practical terms it is a unique reform in business taxation in the world.

SPEECH.PARA: The Taxation Laws Amendment (Company Distributions) Bill will amend the tax law to introduce from 1 July next the full imputation system of company tax which the Treasurer (Mr Keating) announced last December. That is a major reform in business tax which has been welcomed by many participants in Australian business. Once again the Government will be able to go to the people, on 11 July, with a major tax reform under its belt. The new company tax system is formally known as imputation because tax paid at the company level will be imputed or allocated to shareholders by means of credits attached to the dividends that they receive. Such dividends will be known as franked dividends. Franking credits generally resulting from the payment of company tax will be allocated to dividends. An amount equal to the imputation credits attached to franked dividends will be included in the assessable incomes of the resident individual shareholders who will then be entitled to a rebate of tax equal to the amount included in their incomes. That means that dividend incomes will effectively be tax free in the hands of shareholders if they have already borne company tax at the rate of 49c in the dollar. As honourable senators will be aware, under the old company tax system in Australia tax on dividend income was paid twice in effect-once on the company surpluses and once on the personal income of the recipient shareholder.

Dividends will be taxed just once under the Government's new imputation system. No wonder major and key business figures throughout Australia have been supporting Labor's tax reforms. In his address this morning Senator Short of the Opposition referred to them as the `so-called tax reforms', but many people in the business sector and the rest of the community are well aware of the scope and magnitude of the tax reforms which have been brought forward for the Australian people by the Hawke Labor Government.

Under the imputation system if a company makes a profit of, say, $100,000 and as a consequence pays company tax of $49,000 it will now be able to pass on to shareholders tax-free dividends worth some $51,000. In contrast, under the old company tax system a company paid tax on its profits at the rate of 46c in the dollar, and the after-tax profits distributed to the shareholders were then taxed at the shareholders' marginal tax rates. Assuming the tax rate was the former top rate of 60c in the dollar which was applied when Mr Howard was Treasurer, a shareholder's income from dividends was effectively taxed at a rate of not 60c in the dollar but 78.4c in the dollar. Even if a shareholder had a marginal tax rate of 46c in the dollar-the middle rate-the marginal tax rate on dividends in effect would have worked out at not 46c in the dollar but more than 70c in the dollar.

Under the new system, the company tax rate will be aligned with the new top personal marginal tax rate of 49c in the dollar. Honourable senators will recall that, as part of the Hawke Government's tax package, it has cut marginal tax rates across the board. The top marginal rate, for instance, has been cut from 60c, which it was under Mr Howard as Treasurer, to 55c in the dollar at present, and from 1 July it will be reduced to 49c in the dollar. The net effect of that is that no Australian personal taxpayer will pay more than half of his or her extra income in income tax.

The effect of imputation credits is to eliminate further tax on dividends after company tax has been paid. In one of the examples that I gave, the effective tax rate paid by a shareholder falls from 78.4c in the dollar to 49c in the dollar. If the shareholder's marginal tax rate is less than 40c in the dollar under the new regime, the shareholder's tax credit will exceed his tax liability on the dividend. It is interesting and very pleasing to note that this excess credit can be used to reduce tax on the taxpayer's other non-dividend income. However, if the shareholder has no other income on which tax is paid, a cash refund of the imputation credit will not be paid. Dividends which are paid out of untaxed income will remain taxable, as under the present tax law-that is, they will also be taxed at marginal tax rates when received by the resident shareholder.

Other key features of this legislation are that dividends received by companies from other resident companies will continue to be free of company tax. However, where such company dividends are qualifying dividends under this legislation, the imputation credits may be passed through company structures to benefit, ultimately, individual resident shareholders. Qualifying dividends will be exempt from dividend withholding tax when paid to non-residents. However, dividends paid to non-residents out of company income which has not borne company tax will be liable for the existing 15 per cent dividend withholding tax.

The issue of bonus shares will generally be regarded as the payment of a dividend for the purposes of the imputation system and will be treated under the tax laws in the same way as other dividends. This will mean that such issues will be subject to tax in the hands of an individual recipient but will carry imputation credits where eligible. One of the key features of this legislation is that Division 7 of the Income Tax Assessment Act, which imposes a penalty on private companies that do not distribute a minimum proportion of their taxable incomes, will be abolished in the next financial year, subject to certain transitional rules being adhered to.

The Income Tax (Franking Deficit) Bill will amend the income tax law to impose on companies the liability to pay franking deficit tax. The Income Tax Rates Amendment Bill amends the income tax law to declare the level of company tax at 49c in the dollar in respect of incomes in 1986-87 and subsequent years. The tax on current year incomes will be paid during 1987-88.

I turn to the question of the costs to revenue of these major, historic reforms of business taxation which have been introduced by the Hawke Labor Government. The gross cost to government revenue of the changes involved in introducing imputation is some $775m in a full financial year. Against that will be set the increased revenue which the Government will collect from 1 July from the rise in the general rate of company tax. Overall, the net benefit to taxpayers, the net benefit to the shareholders of businesses, from these changes will be a full $300m in a complete financial year, a very major benefit to the business sector and shareholders.

Earlier today Senator Short claimed that the rise in the company tax rate would be a real killer. But here we can point in black and white to a situation in which, as a result, on balance, of a range of government reforms to business taxation in a full financial year the business sector will not be killed by these reforms; it will be $300m better off, and that is a very major reform of business taxation in Australia. Of course, that is on top of the $4,500m cuts in personal taxes which have been delivered to taxpayers by the Hawke Labor Government. That program of tax reductions began with stage 1 in 1984; stage 2 was introduced in December 1986 and stage 3 of the tax cuts will be delivered to Australian taxpayers on 1 July next. Those tax reforms have involved an increase in the tax free threshold, that is, the amount of tax exempt income available to all taxpayers. They have also involved major reductions in the marginal tax rates and rates in the individual tax brackets. The 43c in the dollar tax rate will be reduced to 40c on 1 July; the 46c in the dollar rate existing at the moment will be cut to 40c in the dollar on 1 July; and, as I mentioned earlier, the existing 55c in the dollar tax rate will be reduced to 49c in the dollar also on 1 July. Those moves have been welcomed by the electorate. Last week I had the opportunity of going around the outback areas of my electorate talking to the people about the tax changes and they were very warmly welcomed indeed. No doubt they will be even more warmly welcomed after 1 July when people see the effect of those tax changes on their weekly or fortnightly pay cheques.

The new tax system, which removes the double taxation of dividends, was very strongly recommended in previous major reports on Australia's financial and taxation system. I refer to the Asprey Taxation Review Committee of 1975. That Committee was appointed by the McMahon Liberal Government; it was not appointed by the Whitlam Government, although it certainly reported to it. It strongly recommended the ending of double taxation of company dividends, as did the 1981 Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System.

In contrast to their pro-business rhetoric, the Liberal and National parties ignored the recommendations of these inquiries during Mr Howard's period as Treasurer between 1977 and 1983. Again I point out that the Asprey report was the result of a decision by a conservative government-the McMahon Liberal Government. It recommended that double taxation of dividends be scrapped, but Mr Howard, who, as Treasurer of this country, had the opportunity in five Budgets to do something about it, ignored the advice of that Committee. Despite the Liberal and National parties' bleatings about lower taxation and stimulating business activity, they did not remove the double taxation of dividends when they had ample opportunity to do so.

Mr Howard was not successful in cutting personal income tax rates. He could not reduce tax on shareholders during the five years he was Treasurer. His record as Treasurer is very stark; it is there for all to read in black and white. The proportion of Australia's gross domestic product taken by taxation rose over the period of the Fraser-Howard Government. The share of Australia's gross domestic product going in taxation was 1.7 percentage points higher at the end of Mr Howard's term as Treasurer than it was at the beginning of the life of the Fraser Government. There is no reason to believe that Mr Howard can go out on the hustings and say that he can deliver tax cuts. He says that he will campaign on taxes, but his record and his period in office show that he clearly is incapable of cutting taxes.

DEBATE.TITLE: MINISTERIAL ARRANGEMENTS

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

—I ask a supplementary question. Does the Minister agree that this action taken by Mr Halfpenny is in defiance of the very substantial majority vote of his union and in defiance of the Arbitration Commission's statement that negotiations are supposed to `continue in an environment free of industrial action'? If he agrees, is he prepared to indicate his public disapproval of action which is being taken by a man who shares with him the privilege of being an endorsed Australian Labor Party candidate for the Senate in the forthcoming election?

—It is often said that politics frequently is about half truths. Unfortunately, industrial relations matters often are not. It is easy in a question of this kind to target Mr Halfpenny as an individual and say that he is responsible for all these things.
—Do you deny that?

—I do not know and the honourable senator does not know either. —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Does the Minister know when the French Government intends to hold a referendum on self-determination for New Caledonia? Does he know what questions are to be asked of those voting and who will be entitled to vote? Does this referendum meet the requirements of the United Nations decolonisation committee as an act of self-determination?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The precise timing of the referendum to be held in New Caledonia is not yet known. It depends on the outcome of an examination by the Constitutional Council in Paris of the enabling legislation that was passed by the French Parliament. However, it does seem very likely that the referendum cannot now be held before the second half of September at the earliest, as distinct from the original anticipation of having it several months earlier than that. In broad terms it seems clear that the options to be put to the voters in the referendum are: First, independence; or secondly, continued association with France with a statute of internal autonomy. As I understand it, there will be little or no elaboration of the precise implications of the options, particularly the independence option, nor will there be the kind of independence in association with France option that has been utilised elsewhere, most notably with the Cook Islands and New Zealand and which has been thought by many people to be one further possible alternative which might reasonably have been put to the New Caledonian people.

ANSWER.PARA: All residents of New Caledonia who have been resident for three years or longer will be entitled to vote. That applies some obvious restriction on the entitlement to vote-which, of course, is welcome. France has made clear that it will not co-operate, however, with the United Nations decolonisation committee in the pursuit of its policy towards New Caledonia. Despite a few small points that can be made in favour of the referendum, such as the three-year proposal, it certainly is the clear view of both the Australian Government and the South Pacific Forum governments that the referendum proposed does not accord with the usual United Nations decolonisation principles or practices. Those principles or practices were spelled out-or one view of them-in a communique issued by the Forum Foreign Ministers who met in New Zealand at the beginning of March when the following points were made, and I quote from the communique of that meeting:

In reaffirming their view that independence for New Caledonia is inevitable and desirable the Forum countries base their position on UN principles and practices which are fundamental to a free and genuine act of self-determination. These require:
(a) a free, honest and genuine choice in any act of self-determination;

(b) the inclusion in the franchise for the act of self-determination of only those who can demonstrate long term residence in and commitment to New Caledonia. It should ensure that the rights and interests of all inhabitants are guaranteed, with special recognition of Kanak rights.
(c) all options being open; including status quo, integration, internal self-government, associated independence, or unqualified independence;
(d) political education for the people so that all options are understood and in particular no options are seen to carry punitive consequences.

No doubt, the whole New Caledonia question will be further considered at the Forum commencing today and the continued applicability of the sorts of positions that were articulated at the Forum Foreign Ministers conference will be reconsidered in the light of recent developments. But as we understand it, that is the position on the referendum and that is the nature of the Australian Government's reaction to that proposal as it stands at this stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask you to ask the Minister to table the papers from which he has quoted.
—Will the Minister table the papers?
—I will table the full version of the document from which I quoted. I do not propose to table the basic notes to the answer but I will certainly table the particular document from which I quoted.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, relates to the difficulties being faced by hospital administrators, both Commonwealth and State, in recruiting and retaining various nursing staff in the various States. The Minister will be aware that the problem has been more significant for the repatriation hospital system because in most States Commonwealth pay rates have tended to fall behind the relevant rates paid by State hospitals over the last few years. Will the Minister outline any efforts being undertaken by his Department to alleviate that situation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Coleman has drawn attention to the very serious shortage of nurses in the repatriation system. I add that there is a serious shortage of nurses in Australia, not only in the repatriation system but also generally. For example, the New South Wales Government has just spent almost half a million dollars seeking to recruit nurses into the State hospital system. I am led to believe that only 11 people responded, which indicates the substantial problems that we are having getting sufficient nurses who are prepared to come and work under the conditions in which they have worked for many years. The particular problem in the repatriation hospital system was that the rates of pay were substantially lower than those paid to nurses in the State hospital system. So the inevitable took place. Many nurses left the repatriation hospital system and went to work for higher rates of pay in the States that had increased salaries for trained nurses.

ANSWER.PARA: We had, therefore, an insufficiency in terms of nurse numbers and in terms of training, and of course there is no career structure to attract women into the nursing profession. I think that has probably resulted for two reasons. Women have a greater variety of careers available to them now than they may have had 15 or 20 years ago. This also reflects the failure of past governments, particularly the previous Liberal-National Party Government, to recognise the problem that was developing over many years as a result of their non-interventionist and non-training policies. These governments not only did not recognise the problem but also did not introduce a career and wage structure that would have rectified the problem before it got out of hand.

I was confronted with that problem when I became Minister in 1983. The Government was also confronted with the difficulties of the wage pause period. The only way in which the Government and the Department could deal with the question of nurses' salaries was under the anomalies provisions of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. It took several years to resolve that point. It has now been resolved in favour of the nurses and they have been awarded matched rates. Senator Coleman would appreciate that this means that I am now able to offer the same rates of pay to repatriation nurses in each State as the State Ministers have been able to offer in their State hospital systems.

Arising out of that decision, the Department is writing to all of those nurses who previously worked in the repatriation system-those who left it for family or other reasons-pointing out that we recognise the career structure nature of the industry and that there has been an imbalance in the salaries, and suggesting that they might seek their interests by returning to work in the repatriation hospital system. If that happens, the fears that have been expressed by Senator Coleman will not be realised and we will be able to carry out our obligation to provide nursing care in the repatriation hospital system.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. ANSWER.PARA: What would happen if a Howard-Bjelke-Petersen government was to be elected in Australia?

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to an article in this morning's Canberra Times newspaper reporting the announcement by the Federal President of the Australian Small Business Association, Mr Peter Boyle, that the ASBA would support candidates `committed to business principles' at the forthcoming Federal election. A number of tax policy proposals which would have serious implications for the interests of small business have recently been floated by various political and academic organisations, and it is not surprising that the ASBA has chosen to take an active role in the election context in seeking to protect its member's interests.
—Order! Ask the question.
—I ask the Minister: Will the Government take action to warn the small business community of the implications of the taxation policy proposals which would threaten this important business sector?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is, of course, no doubt that some of the tax options being peddled by various groups in the country, particularly those being peddled around by the Liberal Party of Australia and Professor Porter's National Priorities Project, would have very detrimental effects on small business. The most obvious of those options, of course, is the introduction of a value added tax, usually referred to as VAT. If that were to happen, for example, every business enterprise would have to register with the Australian Taxation Office and obtain a VAT number. Every registered trader would have to pay tax on all inputs and charge the tax on outputs.
—That was in Keating's White Paper.

—There was no recommendation for a VAT in the White Paper at any stage. Each small business would have to pay the Tax Office the difference between the output tax and the input tax at prescribed intervals and provide appropriate supporting documentation. In the case of small shopkeepers, VAT would have to be paid on all goods bought from wholesalers, electricity, phone bills, repairs to equipment, advertising and so on. A shopkeeper would have to keep track of all invoices and keep records of the VAT numbers of his or her suppliers-not only his or her own VAT number, but records of the VAT numbers of all of his or her suppliers. Where VAT is paid on something that is used partly for private use and partly for business use-such as an electricity or phone bill, where there is some physical association between the business premises and the residence-there would have to be a division of the VAT into claimable and non-claimable parts. ANSWER.PARA: Finally, another thing I would advise small business and the community in general to be very wary of is falling for this seemingly slick proposition that public expenditure on health services for people other than pensioners should be transferred from the public sector to the private sector. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also directed to the Minister for Finance. I ask whether the Minister recalls telling the Australian Labor Party conference in Hobart last year:

QUESTION.PARA: If we had still a public debt interest payment with the same level of outlays as it was in 1982, we would in this financial year have about $4 billion extra to either cut taxes, increase welfare spending or whatever else you wanted to do with it, but because we have run a sequence of high budget deficits we are lumbered with a crippling public debt interest payment which restricts the ability of this government and governments for the foreseeable future to deliver the programmes they would like to deliver elsewhere.

Does the Minister stand by those words? If so, does he agree that had not the present Government run this `sequence of high Budget deficits' there would have been no need for the recent mini-Budget, which sought to cut exactly the same amount referred to by the Minister-$4 billion-from government spending? Does he agree that if the Hawke Government had not been such an irresponsible big spender he would have had the money, and again I quote the Minister, `to either cut taxes or increase welfare spending instead of having to inflict the pain of the mini-Budget on the community'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do recall saying something very similar to that which Senator Walters has quoted. If the honourable thinks she is embarrassing me by repeating it, I advise her to think again. It is true that public debt interest currently requires about 10 per cent of total Commonwealth outlays-a figure of just over $7 billion, I believe, for this financial year. It is not, incidentally, the $55 billion that the Opposition shadow spokesman for finance asserted it to be in his first Press release issued after he took over the shadow finance job. Not even if John Howard had remained Treasurer would interest payments on public debt be as high as the $55 billion that Senator Short claimed it to be in his first Press release in his new capacity.

ANSWER.PARA: The substance of Senator Walters's question is that if there has been a number of Budget deficits of course public debt increases and interest payments accumulate with it. The high Budget deficits started in 1982 and the prospective Budget deficit that we inherited from John Howard for the 1983-84 financial year was almost $10 billion. In one year that prospective Budget deficit that John Howard left behind as a sort of nasty surprise in the little, secret black box for this Government would have accumulated 20 per cent or thereabouts of total Commonwealth debt, but that is not the only thing this Government inherited, of course. In its last year in office the Fraser-Howard team presided over the most serious economic collapse that Australia has seen since 1930. In just one year the Fraser-Howard team destroyed a quarter of a million jobs and left this Government with a double-digit trifecta-I think that is the word-of a $10 billion deficit, inflation running at 11 1/2 per cent and unemployment running at 10 1/2 per cent.

Since Senator Walters has developed an interest in reading my speeches, I commend to her a number of other speeches I have given over the past few years that also draw attention to the fact that because of that collapse of the economy, presided over, if not engineered, by John Howard, there are effects on both the outlay and the revenue sides of the Budget. On the outlays, obviously, if a quarter of a million people lose their jobs in one year-as they did in the last year when John Howard was Treasurer-that entails outlays at present rates of the order of $1.5 billion on unemployment benefits. That is about what it costs to pay unemployment benefits to a quarter of a million people, and a quarter of a million people lost their jobs during the last year of the Fraser-Howard Government and did not get jobs anywhere else. So we had tacked on to that inheritance of the prospective deficit increased outlays of $1.5 billion because of the increased unemployment left to this Government as a legacy by the previous Government.

The story does not stop there. It also means that that quarter of a million people who previously had been employed, receiving wages and paying taxes were receiving unemployment benefits and in most cases probably paying no tax at all. So, to take account of that one needs to add, probably, something between $700m or $800m to the $1.5 billion that is already there.
