The speeches read as follows-
MUTUAL ASSISTANCE IN CRIMINAL MATTERS BILL 1987

This Bill was first introduced into the House of Representatives on 22 October 1986. The Bill is now being re-introduced in a significantly amended form. The most important of these amendments enable Australia to provide, and request, assistance concerning freezing and forfeiture of the proceeds of crime. I will refer later in more detail to this aspect of the Bill.

This Bill will provide a legislative basis for Australia to enter into arrangements with other countries whereby it can request and grant assistance in criminal matters. The assistance will relate both to the investigation and prosecution of crime. This Bill represents a significant initiative of this Government in its fight against organised and international crime.

At the conclusion of the Special Premiers Conference in April 1985 the Prime Minister committed the Government to actively pursuing opportunities for increased co-operation with other countries in combatting crime. The Final Report of the Royal Commission into the Activities of the Nugan Hand Group which was presented on 12 July 1985 recommended, inter alia, that the Commonwealth Government give consideration to up-grading the priority accorded to the establishment of modern mutual assistance agreements. At the 7th UN Crime Congress in Milan in 1985, Australia was instrumental in proposing, and having unanimously carried, a resolution calling for greater international co-operation in combatting organised crime and urging all Governments to give urgent attention to the development of mutual assistance arrangements.

This Bill in particular will enable Australia, in co-operation with other countries, to deprive criminals of offshore havens in which to hide their profits. The Attorney-General's recent discussions overseas, particularly in the United States and Switzerland, have completely confirmed the need for legislation in this area if Australia is to effectively carry out its international responsibilities in combatting crime. The Attorney- General was impressed in the course of those recent discussions with the number of countries which expressed interest in the early completion of mutual assistance arrangements with Australia.

In early 1985 the Attorney-General established a task force to extend and modernise Australia's extradition arrangements with other countries. In that short period of time the Attorney-General has signed 13 extradition treaties. Negotiations have also been opened up with another 27 countries. The task force has also commenced the process of developing mutual assistance arrangements with other countries based on this Bill. I would like to take this opportunity to express appreciation on behalf of the Attorney-General of the tremendous work done by officers of his Department and of the Department of Foreign Affairs in the development of legislation as well as treaties and other arrangements. The work of these officers has resulted in a treaty making process without precedent in this country's history. I am confident that the good work of the task force will continue.

This Bill has been the subject of extensive consultation with the States and the Northern Territory. The success of this proposed legislation, and the international arrangements for mutual assistance, will depend heavily on close co-operation and understanding between the Commonwealth and the States. The Bill also ensures that rights of persons are properly protected in accordance with Australian standards of justice. The Bill reflects the principles of the Commonwealth Scheme for Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters agreed at the Commonwealth Law Ministers meeting in Harare in July 1986.

I shall now turn to the principal features of the Bill. Clause 5 of the Bill makes it clear that its object is to facilitate the provision and obtaining by Australia of international assistance in criminal matters in areas which include:
(a) the obtaining of evidence, documents and other articles;
(b) the provision of documents and other records;
(c) the location and identification of witnesses or suspects;
(d) the execution of requests for search and seizure;
(e) the making of arrangements for persons to give evidence or assist in investigations;
(f) the forfeiture or confiscation of property in respect of offences;
(g) the recovery of pecuniary penalties in respect of offences;
(h) the restraining of dealings in property, or the freezing of assets, that may be forfeited or confiscated or that may be needed to satisfy pecuniary penalties imposed, in respect of offences;
(i) the location of property that may be forfeited, or that may be needed to satisfy pecuniary penalties imposed, in respect of offences; and
(j) the service of documents.

The Bill's real function is to provide a legislative basis for Australia to honour the obligations it will be assuming in treaties and arrangements thereby ensuring that other countries will honour their obligations to Australia.

Clause 7 of the Bill provides that the Act may be applied to a foreign country specified in the regulations. Clause 8 is a particularly important clause in that it sets out circumstances in which the Attorney-General can refuse assistance. These exceptions to the provision of assistance are designed to ensure that national and State interests are safeguarded and that no injustice or oppression is caused to individuals. The substantive parts of the Bill also reflect the concern that Australia should not, in responding to a foreign request for assistance, unfairly disadvantage any individual.

Part II of the Bill empowers the Attorney-General to authorise a magistrate in Australia to take evidence and have documents and articles produced for transmission to a foreign country for use in proceedings in that country. The person to whom the foreign proceedings relate is entitled to be represented at the hearing in Australia as is any other person giving evidence or producing documents or other articles at the hearing. The relevant authority of the foreign country is also entitled to be represented.

Part III of the Bill deals with search and seizure at the request of foreign countries. The foreign country must specify the reasonable grounds which it has for believing that a thing which is relevant to a proceeding or investigation involving a serious offence against the law of that country is located in Australia. A search warrant may not issue unless the foreign offence carries a maximum penalty of at least 12 months imprisonment.

Part IV of the Bill deals with arrangements for persons and prisoners to travel to a foreign country at that country's request or to Australia at Australia's request to give evidence in a criminal proceeding or to assist a criminal investigation. Most serious organised crime has international dimensions. It is accordingly vital that Australia have arrangements whereby persons overseas, whether prisoners or not, can be transferred to Australia to give evidence or assist investigations. Safeguards are built into the procedures established. For example the person is entitled to immunity from prosecution both in respect of offences allegedly committed prior to departure from the foreign country to travel to Australia to give evidence to or assist an investigation and also in respect of the evidence he or she gives except for perjury.

The Bill will enable Australia to significantly ease the task of foreign investigation and prosecution agencies in cases where crucial evidence or witnesses are in Australia. Australia will also benefit by being able to make requests for similar assistance pursuant to the arrangements it will be entering into. For example Australia will be able to seek by compulsory process access to banking and other financial records in foreign countries.

It is vital that Australia be able to give effect to foreign forfeiture and confiscation orders in relation to the proceeds of overseas criminal activity where those proceeds are located in Australia. In turn it is also vital that Australia be able to seek the forfeiture and confiscation of the proceeds of crime committed in Australia where the proceeds are found overseas. The proceeds of criminal activity, regardless of where found, should be denied to those persons who have obtained them and hopefully returned to the society which was a victim of the criminal conduct to which those proceedings relate.

The major amendment to the form of the Bill in which it was originally introduced into the House of Representatives on 22 October 1986 is the addition of a new Part VI concerning the proceeds of crime. This Part will link in the provisions of the Proceeds of Crime Bill 1987 and permit, at the international level, forfeiture and confiscation by Australia at the request of foreign countries and vice versa.

Part VII of the Bill provides for service of foreign criminal process in Australia. The Part also contemplates that Australian criminal process will in turn be able to be served in a foreign country. The Government attaches great importance to development of a comprehensive international framework of mutual assistance treaties and arrangements. Major crime is becoming increasingly international in scope. It is imperative that greater international co-operation and assistance be introduced into the investigation and prosecution processes to enable major criminal suspects to be brought to justice. This Bill provides the legislative backing for Australia to enter into these international arrangements.

While it is not possible to estimate the resource and cost implications of this Bill, it is clear that Australia will derive considerable benefit from assistance from other countries. I should mention in this regard that Australia has already received significant assistance from a number of foreign countries. I mention in particular Switzerland where significant funds associated with Australian narcotics trafficking have been frozen. However, to extend and improve this kind of assistance Australia must be in a position to extend assistance to other countries. The cost of providing that assistance will be at least offset, and probably outweighed, by the value of the assistance Australia receives. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
MUTUAL ASSISTANCE IN CRIMINAL MATTERS (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1987

This Bill was first introduced into the House of Representatives on 22 October 1986. The Bill is now being re-introduced in a significantly amended form. The Bill now amends various Commonwealth Acts as a consequence of provisions in the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Bill 1987. The Bill amends the Director of Public Prosecutions Act to enable the Director to appear and grant indemnities in proceedings under the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Act 1987. The Bill repeals provisions in the Australian extradition legislation in relation to the taking of evidence for the purposes of criminal proceedings overseas since the substance of those provisions are now included in the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matter Bill 1987.

In addition, the Bill amends the Migration Act 1958 to make provision for the entry into Australia and departure of persons who are non-citizens whose presence is required for purposes connected with the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Act 1987. The amendments to the Migration Act also enable deportation of such persons should they remain in Australia longer than permitted for purposes connected with the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Bill 1987 and who have not acquired an entry permit or become an Australian citizen. The Australian Citizenship Act 1948 is amended so that persons permitted to enter Australia for purposes connected with the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Bill 1987 shall not be able to take advantage of their presence in Australia for the purposes of applying for Australian citizenship. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
PROCEEDS OF CRIME BILL 1987

This Bill provides some of the most effective weaponry against major crime ever introduced into this Parliament. Its purpose is to strike at the heart of major organised crime by depriving persons involved of the profits and instruments of their crimes. By so doing, it will suppress criminal activity by attacking the primary motive-profit-and prevent the re-investment of that profit in further criminal activity.

All the evidence available to Government from Royal Commissions and other inquiries in recent years suggests that major crime, particularly drug trafficking and serious fraud on the revenue, is growing and is becoming increasingly international in scope. Traditional methods of punishment by imprisonment and fine are not enough. Stronger measures are called for. Further, measures are required to target not only the pushers and others physically involved in criminal activity but also those who direct, finance and reap the most reward from crime.

The Bill provides a mechanism for the tracing, freezing and confiscation of the proceeds of indictable offences committed against the laws of the Commonwealth and of the Territories. The Bill confers on police new powers to assist in following the money trail, requires financial institutions to retain documents necessary to preserve the money trail and creates new offences such as money laundering and organised fraud. In addition, the Bill also provides the mechanism to enforce orders made under corresponding State laws which affect the freezing and confiscation of property located in a Territory. The Bill, when taken together with the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Bill, enables Australian freezing and confiscation orders to be enforced overseas and orders made in foreign countries in relation to foreign offences to be enforced against assets located in Australia. These international measures of co-operation are vital in the fight against the growing internationalism of major crime.

This Bill is the end product of a resolution passed by the Special Premiers Conference on Drugs as a result of which the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General agreed upon the terms of the draft model Bill after extensive consultation. South Australia, Victoria and New South Wales have enacted legislation broadly along the lines of the model scheme agreed to by the Standing Committee. The general regime of this Bill, insofar as it relates to the freezing and confiscation of assets, is also consistent with that model. However, this Bill goes far beyond the regime approved by the Standing Committee in providing new effective powers to permit law enforcement agencies to follow the money trail, creating new offences of money laundering and organised fraud, providing for the statutory forfeiture of property following conviction of certain serious offences and requiring financial institutions to preserve the money trail for subsequent taxation and law enforcement purposes.

This Bill forms part of a package of Bills, each of which contains measures which significantly advance the fight against organised crime, but when taken together constitute a comprehensive package which is designed to effectively suppress organised crime in Australia. The package will include the Proceeds of Crime Bill now before the House, the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Bill, the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Bill, a revision and codification of the laws relating to Extradition, and new legislation requiring certain cash transactions to be reported to a central Government agency.

The Proceeds of Crime Bill represents a careful balancing of effective new powers for law enforcement agencies in the freezing and confiscation of assets against the need for adequate mechanisms for the protection of interests of third parties, who have an interest in property which is the subject of forfeiture but who have no involvement in the commission of the offence and no knowledge of the origin of the property.

The scheme has been carefully designed to provide the greatest possible flexibility to law enforcement agencies to ensure that the legislation effectively meets as many different factual situations as possible. For example, search warrants and restraining orders may be sought immediately before charges are laid, or at any subsequent time. Confiscation orders likewise may be sought at the time of conviction and, in fact, form part of the sentencing process where sufficient evidence is available to bring confiscation proceedings at the time, and the matter can be expeditiously dealt with by the court as part of the sentencing process. In other cases, the application for confiscation can be made at any time up to six months after the date of the relevant conviction. Innocent third parties may seek to have their property excluded from freezing and confiscation proceedings as early as the hearing of the application of the restraining order, at any time during the currency of the restraining order, at the determination of the application for confiscation proceedings, and at any time within six months after confiscation. The regime of this Bill will be in addition to other Commonwealth and Territory legislative provisions which provide for the forfeiture of property or the imposition of pecuniary penalties such as the provisions in Division 3 of Part XIII of the Customs Act 1901.
Contents of Bill
The detailed explanation of the contents of the Bill is contained in the Explanatory Memorandum. Mr President, I wish only to refer at this stage to the more important features of the Bill:

The Bill applies both within and outside Australia to enable courts to make restraining and confiscation orders in relation to property located outside Australia and profits derived and realised outside Australia;
Confiscation orders under the proposed legislation may take the form of either forfeiture orders, or orders for pecuniary penalties, or a combination of both where this is appropriate;
Once a forfeiture order is made, the property vests in equity in the Commonwealth. Registrable property does not vest in law until registration procedures have been complied with;

Third parties who can establish that they were not in any way involved in the commission of the offence are able to seek exemption of their property from the operation of the forfeiture order, or to have the forfeiture order discharged in respect of that property. As a general rule, third parties must challenge the forfeiture order within six months unless granted special leave by the court;

Pecuniary penalty orders, on the other hand, may only be made against the defendant. These orders require the court to assess the benefit which the offender derived directly or indirectly from the commission of the offence, assigning a monetary value to that benefit and making a pecuniary penalty order equal to that amount. Once such an order has been made it can be enforced as a civil debt and is provable in bankruptcy;

The legislation contains provisions to enable courts to look behind the legal ownership of property to determine whether that property is subject to the effective control of the defendant, having regard to such things as share holdings or directorships of companies, any trust that has a relationship to the property, family and business relationships and the like;

This Bill also provides for statutory forfeiture in limited circumstances. Where a person is convicted of a serious offence, defined to be a narcotics offence involving a trafficable quantity of drugs which constitutes a breach of Commonwealth or Territory law, an organised fraud offence, or an offence of money laundering the proceeds of such drug trafficking or organised fraud, that person is liable to have all property which is the subject of a restraining order six months after the date of his or her conviction forfeited by force of statute, unless the person can establish that the property was lawfully acquired;

The Bill also deals with the problem of persons, or their associates, moving property beyond the jurisdiction once they become aware that charges are about to be laid. Part III of the Bill confers new and far reaching powers on police officers to seize property which is tainted and to hold such property for 14 days pending the making of a restraining order over the property. Such seizures can arise in three circumstances, namely, by consent, under judicial warrant or without judicial warrant in emergencies. Restraining orders may be made immediately before charges are laid. Under a restraining order, the court may direct that property specified in the order not be disposed of, or otherwise dealt with, by any person other than in accordance with the terms of the order or may require the Official Trustee to take custody and control of the property specified in the order. A court may make a restraining order where it is satisfied that there are reasonable grounds for believing that the defendant committed the offence alleged and that the property the subject of the application is either tainted property or may be required to satisfy a pecuniary penalty order;

Restraining orders may be varied by a court on the application of any person holding an interest in property the subject of the order. Restraining orders may be registered on registers of title and, when combined with pecuniary penalty orders, give rise to a statutory charge over the property. Contravention of a restraining order constitutes an offence punishable by a fine of $10,000 or 5 years imprisonment or both in the case of a natural person and a fine of $50,000 in the case of a body corporate;

Part IV of the Bill confers wide-ranging and effective powers on law enforcement officers to gain access to documents relevant to following the money trail and transferring tainted property. The first of these new measures is a production order, made by a person who is a judge of a Supreme Court, directing a person who has property tracking documents in his or her possession or control to produce such documents to a law enforcement officer or, alternatively, to make them available for inspection by such an officer. A breach of a production order constitutes an offence. Where it is inappropriate to seek a production order, either because property cannot be identified with sufficient particularity or because there are grounds to believe that a production order is unlikely to be complied with or may prejudice effective law enforcement, a search warrant may be granted to search for and seize property tracking documents;

A major new initiative is the introduction of monitoring orders, made by a person who is a judge of a Supreme Court, directing a financial institution to give information over specified periods of time to law enforcement authorities about transactions conducted through accounts held by a particular person. Monitoring orders are only available in relation to serious offences (involving narcotic drugs, organised fraud or money laundering the proceeds of drug trafficking or organised fraud);

As part of the process of enabling law enforcement agencies to follow the money trail and to assist in the investigation of tax evasion offences, the legislation places a statutory obligation on financial institutions to retain certain records. Records which relate to the opening of accounts must be retained in original form for 7 years after closure of the relevant account and all other documents necessary to reconstruct transactions in excess of $200 must be retained for a period of 7 years after the transaction in original or some other form, including micro-fiche. Consultation has taken place with financial institutions in relation to these measures;

Part V of the Bill creates two new offences relating to money laundering. The first of these is a serious offence of engaging in money laundering where the person knows or ought reasonably to have known that property is, in fact, the proceeds of crime. Such a crime must be either an indictable offence against a law of the Commonwealth, or of a Territory, or a drug trafficking offence which was committed overseas which would have constituted an offence against Australian law had the offence been committed in Australia. The legislation also creates a less serious indictable offence of laundering property which is reasonably suspected of being proceeds of crime. This offence is very similar to the offence of possession of goods reasonably suspected of having been stolen, which exists in most jurisdictions and has proved to be an effective law enforcement tool against theft;

The legislation also creates a new offence of organised fraud which is constituted by acts and omissions which constitute 3 or more public fraud offences from which the person has derived substantial benefit. Public fraud offences are breaches of ss 29d and 86a of the Crimes Act 1914 and ss 5, 6, 7 and 8 of the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act 1980. This offence is specifically designed for persons who have been engaged in a pattern of conduct, over a period of time, from which they have benefitted to the detriment of society. The Government has not followed the American precedents which centre around concepts of sophisticated methods, organisation or planning and specific monetary limits. Some of the most effective fraudulent activity has resulted from schemes of utmost simplicity;

The Bill also provides for the problem of dealing with absconders. In certain circumstances, a person who has absconded can be taken to have been convicted of an offence and be liable to confiscation proceedings. Before a confiscation order can be made against an absconder the court must be satisfied that the person has, in fact, absconded and that the person has either been committed for trial in respect of the offence or that a reasonable jury properly instructed could find the person guilty of the offence on the basis of the evidence put before it.

Mr President, these are the major features of the Proceeds of Crime Bill. The Bill will give to law enforcement authorities effective and comprehensive means to carry on the fight against major crime. The Bill will also require our law enforcement authorities to develop more sophisticated skills in tracking, analysing and building up data on financial transactions of criminals. The development of these skills is essential to the success of the measures in this Bill.
Financial Impact Statement

I believe that this Bill will result in significant financial benefit to the Commonwealth, the States and foreign countries with which Australia has mutual assistance arrangements. I also believe that this Bill will return benefits which will greatly outweigh its administrative costs. The Bill provides mechanisms which not only deny to the perpetrators the proceeds of crime but also return those proceeds to society. The Bill will also provide mechanisms to return significant revenue to the Commonwealth.

It is proposed that there be a special trust fund established to receive the funds generated under this legislation and apply those funds specifically to finance further measures by law enforcement authorities in their fight against crime. This would mean that not only will criminals be denied their profits but those very profits will be reinvested in the fight against major crime.

As honourable senators will be aware, the Attorney-General has recently returned from a visit to the United States and Europe which involved discussions on measures to attack the proceeds of crime, international mutual assistance and extradition. He was particularly impressed with the way in which the United States is using legislation on proceeds of crime to deprive criminals of many millions of dollars and reapply that money in their fight against crime. He was also impressed, in his discussions with those countries, by the increasing recognition of the need to adopt measures of the kind contemplated in this Bill and to greatly increase international cooperation in this area. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
PROCEEDS OF CRIME (MISCELLANEOUS AMENDMENTS) BILL 1987

This Bill contains a number of amendments to three Acts to ensure the effectiveness of the Proceeds of Crime Bill 1987. In the development of the Proceeds of Crime Bill 1987 the Government has been concerned to ensure that artificial devices cannot be used to defeat the operation of the legislation. One such artificial device which has the potential for defeating the operation of pecuniary penalty orders made against offenders is the mechanism of bankruptcy. During the currency of the bankruptcy all property of the bankrupt vests in the trustee of the bankruptcy and can therefore, in the absence of special provisions, be put beyond the reach of the Commonwealth and effectively laundered when the surplus property returned to the bankrupt after the risk of confiscation proceedings has passed.
Bankruptcy Act 1966

One consequence of an offender becoming bankrupt prior to confiscation would be that any restraining order restraining all of an offender's property pending the making of a pecuniary penalty order would be likely to be revoked on application by the Official Trustee and no further restraining order in relation to that property could be put in place. The existence of a restraining order is a prerequisite to a court making orders for the examination of persons in relation to the affairs of a person under the Proceeds of Crime Bill 1987. To overcome this difficulty, which arises as a consequence of not being able to restrain a bankrupt offender's property, section 12 of the Bankruptcy Act is amended by clause 9 to specifically empower the Director of Public Prosecutions or persons entitled to bring applications for interstate pecuniary penalty orders to apply to the Inspector-General requesting that he exercise his powers to make enquiries and conduct investigations under the Bankruptcy Act.

Section 58 of the Bankruptcy Act is amended to enable pecuniary penalty orders and interstate pecuniary orders to be enforced against property of the bankrupt which does not vest in the trustee of the bankrupt. Section 60 of the Bankruptcy Act is amended to ensure that proceedings under the Proceeds of Crime Bill can not be discontinued or stayed until all bankruptcy proceedings have been concluded. The amendment to section 82 of the Bankruptcy Act effected by clause 8 enables pecuniary penalties and interstate pecuniary penalty orders to be proved as civil debts payable to the Commonwealth in bankruptcy whether such orders are made before or during the bankruptcy.

Section 148 has been amended to enable the DPP, or persons entitled under State law to apply for an interstate pecuniary penalty order, to apply to a court for an order preventing the distribution of the surplus of a bankruptcy back to the bankrupt. Where an order has been made by the court preventing the distribution of the surplus and a pecuniary penalty order is subsequently made against the bankrupt defendant, the Commonwealth would be in the position to enforce the pecuniary penalty order by way of warrant execution against the surplus held by the Official Trustee. Clause 10 amends section 153 of the Bankruptcy Act to ensure that a pecuniary penalty order debt is not extinguished upon the bankrupt's discharge from the bankruptcy.
Cheques and Payment Orders Act 1986

The Proceeds of Crime (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 1987 amends the Cheques and Payment Orders Act 1986 to require the retention of cheques by financial institutions. The provisions of clauses 12 and 13 require financial institutions to retain cheques and payment orders in amounts in excess of $200 for a period of 7 years. The provisions mirror clauses 77 and 78 of the Proceeds of Crime Bill which require financial institutions to retain other documents necessary to reconstruct transactions conducted through the institution for the amount in excess of $200.
Crimes Act 1914

Part III of the Bill contains a number of amendments to the Crimes Act 1914. The majority of these amendments increase penalties prescribed for offences which are relevant to preserving of the money trail for the purposes of confiscation of assets.

Clause 14 amends section 18a of the Crimes Act to ensure that pecuniary penalty orders made under the Proceeds of Crime Bill are enforced under the regime set up in that Act and are not treated as other pecuniary penalties and enforced in accordance with State laws as if they were fines imposed by the Court. The maximum penalty for offences against sections 36, 39 and 43 of the Crimes Act has been increased 5 years. These offences deal with fabricating or destroying evidence and attempting to pervert the course of justice. It is likely that criminals will resort more frequently to activities constituting a breach of these provisions in light of the severe penalties which will flow from detection of criminal offences following the introduction of the Proceeds of Crime legislation. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The elimination of the double taxation of dividends by the Hawke Government, which is provided for under the Taxation Laws Amendment (Company Distributions) Bill 1987 and allied Bills, was reported in the international magazine the Economist, dated 7 March 1987. That international business magazine stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The whingers would do better instead to rejoice at another change brought in by the Hawke Government.

The small but vocal minority in the business community will do both themselves and this country a favour if they stop their chorus of whining and whingeing and instead take advantage of the new company tax system and other Government policies which have benefited the business sector, such as the change in the value of the dollar. The article in the Economist went on to say that the new company tax system proposed in this legislation was `the purest imputation system in the world'. That is an accolade from the Economist magazine-one of the more important international business magazines. It went on to say that if such a system were applied to Britain it would probably do more to promote small shareholding than the flotation of British Telecom and British Gas put together. It is clear that informed observers and the authors of the Asprey Taxation Review Committee report and the report of the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System believed that there were significant benefits to be gained from the elimination of double taxation of company dividends. The most important benefit will be to encourage equity financing or share financing of Australian companies. This legislation will help to make share financing and equity financing relatively more attractive to businesses than the various alternatives that are available to them.

It is a matter of historical fact that in Australia in the last few years there has been a very strong trend away from equity financing and share issues towards debt financing of companies and the borrowing by companies to finance expansions. In recent times Australian companies have tended to borrow relatively more from banks than other financial institutions to finance expansion, rather than raise the necessary finance through the stock market by share and equity issues. I refer to figures issued by the Reserve Bank of Australia which show that between 1979 and 1984 the total indebtedness of Australian companies more than doubled, from $23,000m to $52,000m-a very large increase. A large proportion of that growth involves indebtedness overseas, some have foreign owners of debt.

As at 31 March last year Australia's gross external debt was estimated at some $80,000m. More than half of that amount-57 per cent, or $46,000m-was owed by the private sector. One of the large elements of that was the debt owed overseas by the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd. That company alone owed 4.8 per cent of Australia's foreign debt. Australian companies' preference for borrowing funds rather than raising equity has been the real reason for the blow-out in Australia's foreign debt. That has been the underlying trend in the Australian economy which has created this problem-the move that began some years ago away from equity in share issues towards borrowing to finance business activities. To make matters worse, a large percentage of this overseas borrowing has not been used to invest in new plant and equipment, it has not been used to expand Australia's productive base, but to finance takeover activities; to take over existing assets rather than add to the sum total of productive assets in the Australian economy. That is certainly a matter of concern to me as a senator.

The Macquarie Bank estimates that Australia now has to pay some $6,000m a year in interest payments alone just to cover the liabilities of Australian business borrowings abroad. These are business borrowings, not government borrowings. This means that the nation as a whole must earn more export income to pay the interest bill on the foreign debt owed by businesses. At a time when some sections of business are exhorting the Government to reduce its expenditure, some corporate treasurers are exercising very little restraint indeed over their own companies' borrowing activities. I believe that the new company tax system should encourage Australian companies to move away from debt financing by removing the previous bias against equity financing. As I pointed out this morning, under the old company tax system which applied when Mr Howard was Treasurer, returns on equity investments were effectively taxed twice in Australia. They were taxed once as the surpluses of companies and again in the hands of shareholders. That was the reality when Mr Howard was the Treasurer. Debt instruments were taxed, just once-in the hands of the lender when he earned the proceeds from making a loan. Interest payments could be deducted against company tax while dividend payments could not.

I am pleased to say that this legislation, which is before the Parliament now and which provides for dividend imputation credits for individual shareholders in respect of their dividend income, will help reduce the cost bias in the economy against equity investment. It is a very efficient measure. It will help improve the efficiency of the Australian economy by encouraging more investment financed by equities rather than borrowing activities. Scrapping this bias against equity investment meshes in well with the Government's strategy of restructuring the economy towards new export-orientated and import competing industries, to which Senator Button referred in Question Time this afternoon and which were diagnosed by the Japanese investment mission.

With equity investment being more attractive it will be easier for business people to gain the necessary venture capital to start new enterprises. The elimination of the double taxation of dividends will also channel investment away from non-productive goods and services towards productive activities which produce regular and periodic flows of income and regular periodic surpluses which create employment and can reduce the trade imbalance.

The other significant benefit from the elimination of double taxation of dividends will be a substantial tax cut for small business. Under the old company tax system an incorporated sole trader paid tax on his or her company income plus personal tax on the distributed profits when received. The new imputation system will not require the trader to pay personal tax on the distributed profits. This will reduce the tax bill of some small business people by almost 40 per cent, yet we have the nonsense from the Australian Small Business Association, which is entering into this election campaign with the absolute garbage and drivel that it retails around Australia, ignoring the fact that under this legislation-legislation which could not be introduced by a National Party-Liberal Party government and which could not be introduced by Mr Howard when he was Treasurer-this Hawke Government is delivering tax cuts of up to 40 per cent for small business people. Small business is probably the biggest winner from the Government's latest tax reform because tax imputation which is provided for by this legislation will give small business a very large tax cut indeed. It took a Labor government to do it, not the Liberals who are long on rhetoric but short on action.

The introduction of the dividend imputation system from 1 July next is another stage in the Government's strategy to modernise and restructure the Australian economy. It will be one of the final measures in the Hawke Government's tax reform package which aims to improve fairness of the tax system and enhance the prospects of Australia's long term economic growth. The tax reforms are an integral part of a series of major policy measures designed to create the environment for business to become more dynamic and more outward looking. It is very important to note that, while there has been a lot of carping from the Opposition and a lot of negative comment from the Opposition and some vested interests in the community, the fact is that the capital gains tax which was introduced by this Government on 19 September 1985 also will have the effect of making the economy more efficient. I believe the capital gains tax, which is a tax on the increased value of an asset between the time of sale and the time of purchase, will help redirect investment towards productive income producing areas in the economy-those areas which produce regular income flows. In that way it will complement the effect of tax imputation on dividends in improving the efficiency of the economy.

The capital gains tax, I believe, will help redirect activity away from assets which are in relatively short supply. They are the speculative areas of the economy, where people move in on assets, such as land and real estate, which are in relatively short supply with a better than average chance of making capital gains on those assets compared with other assets such as productive plant and equipment which this country so desperately needs. The capital gains tax will tend to focus and direct investment away from those speculative areas, such as central business district real estate-land and buildings. The reason for that was that capital gains in general in Australia were untaxed, apart from a couple of specific sections in the Income Tax Act which taxed particular capital gains. I believe that had a deleterious effect on the efficiency and the productive capacity of the economy. Both the tax imputation arrangements and the capital gains tax will make investment in income-producing assets more attractive. It will foster growth in the economy which, I am pleased to say, will be more soundly based. It will be based on real returns more than on speculative activities, as it has been in the past under a long line of conservative Liberal governments.

The Hawke Government has introduced a range of specific measures to enhance business activity and growth in Australia. These include the implementation of restructuring plans in the steel, motor vehicle and heavy engineering sectors of the economy. These are major steps forward, something that I have been waiting for many years to see in this country. A dose of economic planning has been needed, given our very poor performance over the decades. It is pleasing for me to see that we now have at least some economic planning mechanisms in regard to the vitally important steel, motor vehicle and heavy engineering industries. As a result of those plans which are generating increased investment in those industries we can look forward to larger productive capacities, higher production and an underpinning of the future employment levels.

A 150 per cent tax deduction for research and development expenditure has been introduced by this Government, in addition to direct research and development grants-very important steps forward in boosting business activity. There are special tax deductions for investments in management and investment companies-another form of research and development assistance. There is the 4 per cent depreciation allowance for new income producing buildings, including residential rental premises.

With these measures before us the Government is effectively bringing its tax reform package to a successful conclusion. That package was launched after the National Taxation Summit in 1985. It began with a range of tax cuts in that period. We have had the abolition of the expense account lunches. I am delighted to say that the last free lunch has been eaten in Australia. It introduced the fringe benefits tax. It introduced the historic capital gains tax which, I have pointed out, will have a profound effect in improving the efficiency of the economy. With this legislation it is now introducing the arrangements for giving shareholders credits for tax paid by companies on company profits when shareholders list their dividend incomes in their tax forms.

The final instalment of that tax package, as you will be aware, Madam Acting Deputy President, is the major reductions in personal income tax on 1 July next. There will be tremendous reductions under the Labor Government in average and marginal tax rates, with the top rate being reduced from Mr Howard's 60c in the dollar to 49c in the dollar, the middle rate going down from 46c in the dollar to 40c in the dollar, and the current 43c in the dollar going down to 40c in the dollar. They are tremendous reforms of the tax system. Those major cuts in personal income tax have been financed by our crackdown on tax avoidance-that is what it was-by the proliferation of so-called fringe benefits in the community. We have ensured that the last free lunch has been eaten in Australia. We are saving some $330m a year just by stopping that rort and disgraceful activity. That is helping to fund both this measure, the imputation scheme, and the personal tax cuts which begin on 1 July.

These essential elements of the Government's program to improve the efficiency and flexibility of the Australian economy, I am sure, will be welcomed by the community which will see them as a means to ensure a more efficient, dynamic economy. I am sure that when it votes on 11 July it will be considering these factors very carefully indeed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: — Before the Senate is a package of taxation Bills-the Taxation Laws Amendment (Company Distributions) Bill 1987, Income Tax (Franking Deficit) Bill 1987, Income Tax Rates Amendment Bill 1987, Income Tax Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987 and the Bank Account Debits Tax Amendment Bill 1987-which deal with a wide range of initiatives. This package of Bills deals with a wide range of new obligations which are imposed upon taxpayers to assist officers of the Australian Taxation Office in their investigations. It also increases the corporate tax rate from 46 to 49 per cent and eases slightly the iniquitous substantiation requirements for log books. There is a move towards reducing the double tax on dividend income. Most of these amendments will have far reaching implications. It is unfortunate that the Senate does not have the opportunity to give the careful consideration which these important and substantive changes deserve.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the principal results of the passage of this group of Bills will be to introduce a long awaited system of dividend imputation. It will give effect to a decision which was first announced by Treasurer Keating in September 1985 and which was substantially revised in December last year. In effect, from 1 July imputation will apply to those dividends paid from company profits that have been subject to the new 49 per cent corporate tax rate. Such dividends will be known as franked dividends and will attract an imputation credit.

The essence of how these new arrangements will operate is that the tax paid at company level will be credited to shareholders. Pre-1987 profits and post-1986 profits that are free from tax will not qualify as franked dividends. Where companies are paid tax at a lesser rate for any number of reasons, dividends will attract proportionately fewer imputation credits, that is, the benefit for the shareholder will actually be less. If the shareholder receiving the benefit of the tax credit is subject to a marginal tax rate of less than 49 per cent and his tax credit is in excess of his liability on the dividend, he will be permitted to use the credit to offset other tax on other non-dividend income.

In line with the December revision, the status of franked dividends will be reserved when passing through company structures and the ultimate beneficiaries will be individual resident shareholders. In general, dividends which are paid after 30 June 1987 will be eligible to be franked. However, dividends paid after that date for which the reckoning day, that is, the original date of the issue, is prior to 1 July 1987 are not eligible to be franked. While the revised system is an improvement on the first proposal of the Australian Labor Party that involved levying what is known as a compensatory tax, a number of the features of the proposals of these Bills is not entirely satisfactory. In effect, the Bill is perpetuating a tendency that has become obvious over the last five years to include increasingly complicated formula in our taxation laws.

Throughout the Taxation Laws Amendment (Company Distributions) Bill a succession of formula is referred to for the calculation of such items as potential rebate amounts and franking deficits tax. A glance at the calculation required to find the required franking amount will clearly illustrate the complexities that are contained in this Bill. The fact that it takes over 100 pages in the explanatory memorandum to convey to the reader the essential meaning of a Bill which, in itself, covers only about 40 pages, gives a further indication-should it be required-of the intricacies of the proposals put before the people. What we really need is a simplification of our taxation laws. If the Government were really genuine about reducing double taxation on dividends and establishing equity for all taxpayers in respect of dividends, it would have given serious consideration to making all dividends, for example up to a certain amount, tax free.

The principal areas of concern that I wish to address total seven. Firstly, the new regulations have the potential to cause significant shifts in investment patterns and very few people have addressed this aspect. Secondly, there is the complexity of the proposals. Thirdly, there are misleading claims with regard to shareholder benefits. Fourthly, there is the additional company tax and the extra administrative burdens that will be placed on companies. Fifthly, there is the loss of full benefits of indexing the capital gains tax in the distribution of dividends. Sixthly, there are provisions with regard to trusts in a loss situation which, I think, are inequitable. Seventhly, there are the consequences of the interaction with foreign tax credits legislation that imposes penalties on what I term the wrong sorts of companies.

Firstly, I refer to the significant shifts in investment patterns. As outlined, one of the consequences of this imputation proposal that is of some concern is its potential to cause significant shifts in investment patterns. There could be a move away from rent, interest and royalty returns in favour of investments returning essentially tax free dividends, and this could well be discernible in the medium term. Whether this would be in the long term interest of Australia must be questionable. However, despite the fact that some good reasons exist for investment in areas that return tax free dividends, too great a shift in this direction could have long term repercussions, for example, in raising capital in certain other sectors. Some of the biggest losers from this change of direction could be institutional borrowers and the Commonwealth's loan raising facilities.

Given the potential for loss and the current environment of budget deficits and expenditure cuts, I have my reservations as to whether these imputation proposals will continue for many years in view of the fact that the Government needs to find new sources of taxation revenue. While there is some justification for full imputation in the case of private companies, despite the entity convention and the separation of powers between companies and shareholders, I believe that the separation of powers between the company and shareholders is very much more at arm's length than is the case with private companies and their shareholders. Therefore, there is a case for some taxing of public company dividends in the hands of the shareholders. This could easily be achieved with a withholding tax to the extent of 20 to 25 per cent which is deducted by the company at source. By adopting such a procedure present collections from dividends could be increased as the possibility of taxpayers failing to disclose their dividend receipts would be eliminated. Such a measure might prove to be more palatable than, for example, a wealth tax which is certainly on the agenda of some of the colleagues of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Senator Gietzelt.

There are also misleading claims regarding shareholder benefits. Claims about the benefits that will accrue to shareholders under imputation have, in many cases, been quite misleading. An end to the double taxation of dividends is to be welcomed and will no doubt go a long way, or part way, towards achieving its stated goal of increasing the availability of equity finance by making share investment more attractive. However, confusion has been created in the public mind by a plethora of articles dealing with this very complex proposal which has obscured the fact that not all dividend distributions will be tax free in the shareholders hands. Just how `tax free' dividends will be will depend on the tax strategies of the individual companies and their often complex domestic and international operations.

For a shareholder to receive benefits under this new scheme the company, which is actually distributing the dividends, must have credits in its franking account. The circumstances in which these credits arise are outlined in Part IIIAA of the Taxation Laws Amendment (Company Distributions) Bill 1987. For full imputation to occur the company must be a resident of Australia for more than half the year of income, the shareholder must be a resident in Australia for benefit, and the company tax must be paid at the full 49 per cent rate on the profits on which the dividend is drawn. Should the company have accumulated profits, but, for example, incur a loss in the current year and therefore have a reduced tax liability, it will receive fewer credits and therefore will be able only partially to frank its dividends.

Problems for the investor in finding out which companies will offer the greatest benefits from imputation naturally will arise. While the rules of the proposed legislation specify the minimum extent to which the dividend may be franked, companies are given some latitude as to the maximum extent to which the dividends may be franked. As a general rule, a dividend is franked to the extent allowed by the credits in the franking account at the date of the payment of that dividend. However, companies must pro-rate franking dividends where funds in the franking account are insufficient to fully cover all future commitments to dividend distribution. That means committed future dividends, as defined in the interpretation section of the Bill. It is possible, therefore, to imagine a situation in which shareholders may not get a fully franked dividend, even where a company pays the 49 per cent rate, due to the commitments to pay future dividends.

Next, losses of tax credits to shareholders may also occur where dividends have been underfranked because clause 160apx provides that where the required franking amount is greater than 10 per cent of the dividend and the dividend is not franked, a franking debit will arise equal to the required franking amount. This will have the effect of reducing the franking account balance otherwise available for franking future dividends. Thus shareholders will suffer the consequences of an administrative error which has been made by the company. An extra burden is also placed on companies. The burdens of these proposals on Australian companies essentially are twofold. There is a steep increase in the company tax rate from 46 to 49 per cent, which is against the international trend. It imposes substantial administrative duties and costs. The Treasurer tells us that the cost of these changes will be $775m and will be offset in part by the increase in the company tax rate. This additional impost will be disastrous for companies trying to find funds for much needed investment in our straitened economic environment. It is small wonder that companies are considering, or have spoken about, moving their headquarters off-shore, including Elders and the Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd.

Companies that have shown the confidence to retain Australia as their base and have expanded their operations overseas in an attempt to win foreign capital will now be disadvantaged by the proposals before the Senate. So organisations that have learned to operate successfully in a deregulated and extremely competitive international environment unfortunately will be penalised. This is so because only profits on which Australian tax has been paid may be used to generate franked dividends. So where a company receives a significant portion of its profits from overseas, its capacity to distribute fully franked dividends to shareholders will be substantially reduced.

Let me give a case in point. The ANZ Bank has successfully expanded operations by acquiring Grindleys Bank, which now forms part of its operations. In 1986, for example, nearly 40 per cent of its pre-tax earnings came from outside Australia. It is this type of activity that the Government has been promoting as a remedy to the long term problems which have been confronting Australian industry. Despite this, it is putting proposals forward in this package of Bills before the Senate today that will discriminate against such companies as the ANZ Bank. I apologise to it for singling it out, but it is one of many companies trying to do the right thing in pursuing this line. It is strange encouragement indeed to penalise them.

In addition, this very complex legislation places a very heavy administrative burden on companies issuing dividends. They will now be required to remit more detailed statements to shareholders on payment of dividends. They will have to maintain a franking account in each franking year and carry out a reconciliation at the end of each franking year. They will have to retain these additional records pertaining to franking-type balances for a further seven years. So the intricacies involved in calculating the franking dividends mean that the maintenance of these records will be no simple task. However, it will be crucial for company directors to have up to date information on the state of the franking account to make appropriate decisions on dividend issues in the best interests of shareholders.

The impact of this company distributions Bill will be to favour some companies over others. This is unfortunate-it discriminates. The encouragement to pay more franked dividends and thus attract greater shareholder interest will have the effect of draining companies of capital. That will be disastrous. Such a situation will operate in favour of established companies and at the cost of new companies. It is these new companies that require a very much greater proportion of percentage of their capital to be reinvested to establish themselves in the market. Shareholders surely will be more inclined to invest in companies that are distributing franked dividends than in those that are not. This may result in a catch-22 situation where the companies in most need of capital are the least likely to attract it. This is unfortunate.

Private companies too, by and large, are likely to receive a greater benefit from the proposals of this package than are public companies. After the abolition of Division 7 tax they will no longer be liable to pay tax on their undistributed profits-and we welcome that. While the new regulations in theory would have the same impact on both private and public companies, the realities of their structures will mean that certain of the proposals will have their greatest impact on public companies. That is unfortunate. So not only will the additional burden be placed on companies, but the requirements that will be placed on the Australian Taxation Office will also be increased.

Under Division 3 of Part IIIaa a company will be able to request an estimated debit determination from the Commissioner of Taxation when it anticipates a future reduction in its franking surplus. By reducing the franking surplus on that basis the company may avoid creating a franking deficit that may result in liability to franking deficit tax. The monitoring of the company's adherence to the new rules will also be a mammoth task. A less work intensive, less complex, piece of legislation to implement the franking of dividends would be much more appropriate when the pressure is on for a reduction in the size of Australia's public sector. Currently, one-third of our work force is on the government payroll. So the States are being forced into tightening up their public sectors, yet the Federal Government is proposing legislation that could well require even more workers to handle this new legislation before us.

There is also the problem of the indexation of capital gains tax when income derived as a result of that gain flows through in the form of dividends. Under the provisions of this legislation, much of the benefit of the indexation of capital gains will be lost. I make that quite clear. This will be so where a company pays tax on the indexed proportion of capital gains and then distributes the entire capital gain to shareholders. In such cases, the franking credits that accrue to the company will be insufficient fully to frank the entire dividend distribution. Consequently, the indexed portion of the capital gain will be fully assessable in the hands of the shareholders if distributed as a dividend. Given the Government's claim that an asset which increases in value at no more than the rate of inflation bears no capital gains tax, the taxation of such a dividend flowing from such gains in the hands of shareholders seems to be quite contrary to the original intention not to tax capital gains.

A further inconsistency that comes to light on closer scrutiny of this legislation is the condition that relates to trust in a loss situation. The underlying principle of the majority of the Bill is that shareholders will benefit from a tax that has been paid at the company tax level. In line with this concept, imputation rebates will pass through companies, partnerships and, in some cases, trusts finally to benefit individual shareholders. But in the case of companies and partnerships, in a loss situation, imputation rebates on dividends received by them will continue to flow on to shareholders. We read in part A of the explanatory memorandum at page 15:
. . . no such benefit will flow to beneficiaries where a trust has no net income or incurs a loss.

The logic underlying the distinction in this case of losses quite escapes me. Then we have the problem of the foreign tax credits. The major problem with the interrelationship of the new imputation regulations and the foreign tax credit system is that it results in investment overseas becoming a less desirable proposition for Australian companies and it discriminates against those companies that already gain revenue from overseas operations. It has become less attractive because the companies will not be able to pay fully tax-free dividends from this off-shore income, as I mentioned earlier. For example, a company with operations in the United Kingdom will pay tax at a rate of 35 per cent. When that company repatriates the profits from the off-shore operation to Australia it will be required to pay additional tax to cover the shortfall between tax paid in the United Kingdom and the new Australian company tax rate of 49 per cent. In this case, the extra tax payable would be 14 per cent. Under these regulations, franking credits will accrue only on the 14 per cent tax paid in Australia; therefore, the imputation credits flowing to shareholders will be considerably diminished. For investors wishing to gain maximum benefit from their shareholdings, companies that can offer only minimum imputation credits on dividends will certainly be a less attractive proposition.

I would now like to take some time to comment on the more important features of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987. I wish to deal with the substantiation of car expenses. The relaxation of log book requirements to substantiate business car expenses is a welcome move, although I believe an alternative could well have been produced. The onerous task of maintaining detailed log books for the whole year will now be replaced by the requirement of a continuous record for a 12-week period. However, I would like to note that, although similar amendments to the fringe benefits tax legislation have been announced, this Bill does not make provision for such changes.

Because of the shortage of time I will now move to the powers of the Commissioner of Taxation. The section of the Bill that is of most concern is that relating to the extension of the powers of the Commissioner of Taxation-I refer here to clause 62 of Schedule 4. The amendment will require taxpayers to give assistance to investigators in the Australian Taxation Office rather than just allow a right of access. This distinction is quite significant. I accept the proposition that adequate measures need to be taken to enable tax avoidance to be uncovered. However, there has been an increasing trend by this Government in its campaign to nail people, to cast the ordinary taxpayer as a criminal, and this is unfortunate.

While these increased investigatory powers and their extension to pay as you earn provisions may appear on the surface to be reasonable, they open up avenues whereby the civil liberties of honest people may be infringed. I hope that my colleague Senator Puplick will elaborate on this later. I am sure that this prospect will be quite unacceptable to all honest, law abiding citizens. Of course, the existence of these powers does not automatically mean that tax officers will make unreasonable demands of taxpayers. I believe that they will not and, on the whole, this should not be the case. However, I remind the Senate that there have been a number of cases in the past where taxpayers have found cause to complain about their treatment by the Taxation Office. It is my concern that the extension of investigatory powers may foster an attitude in officialdom that, pursued to the extreme, may cause an infringement of individual rights. We should, therefore, be aware of this possibility and we should be cautious of enshrining in legislation the sorts of conditions that may give rise to it.
Debate interrupted.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Legal Aid: Mr M. P. Jess

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McIntosh Sen G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 17 February 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Would the Attorney-General advise the amount of legal aid that has been claimed by or paid to Michael Patrick Jess under the provisions of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act in connection with proceedings commenced by him in the Federal Court of Australia, Industrial Division, in Matter Nos. 1 and 9 of 1984.

(2) Would the Attorney-General further advise why legal aid continues to be paid by the Government to Mr Jess or his solicitors in those Federal Court proceedings when-(a) the solicitor for Mr Jess has informed the Federal Court that they lost contact with him, yet they are still pursuing his action; and (b) a Judge of the Federal Court has given judgment that one of the legal actions begun by Mr Jess was ``instituted without reasonable cause''.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Financial assistance under section 141A of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act 1904 was authorised in June 1984 for Mr Jess's costs of proceedings Nos. 1 and 9 of 1984. Mr Jess, the applicant in those proceedings, was successful. However, the Respondents (26 individuals and the Amalgamated Metals Foundry & Shipwrights' Union) lodged appeals (Nos. 11 and 14 of 1984) against those decisions. Financial assistance was authorised for Mr Jess's costs a respondent to the appeals. In October 1984, the appeals were allowed in part. After the appeals the original matters (Nos. 1 and 9 of 1984) came on again for rehearing before a single judge, who handed down his judgment on 23 July 1986. In the course of that judgment his Honour stated No. 9 of 1984 had been instituted without reasonable cause because it sought the same relief from the same respondents. His Honour then made a costs order against the applicant in respect of No. 9 of 1984. However, his Honour did not consider that No. 1 of 1984 had been instituted vexatiously or without reasonable cause.
The following payments have been made by the Commonwealth in respect of Mr Jess's costs:
Mr Jess's solicitors have not yet submitted their account for the rehearing.

(2) Financial assistance has not been authorised for any proceedings commenced after the judgment delivered on 23 July 1986. However, Mr Jess's solicitors have applied on his behalf for financial assistance for an appeal against the costs order made on 23 July 1986. This application will receive further consideration on receipt of information requested from the solicitors by letter dated 8 September.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation, upon notice, on 19 February 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister for Aviation aware that in European countries such as Germany, France and Switzerland, aircraft landing fees are determined in part by the noise level emitted by the particular aircraft, that is, the higher the noise level the higher the landing fee.

(2) Has the Minister's Department or any other organisation conducted a feasibility study into the adoption of tax incentives vis-a-vis higher landing fees for noisy aircraft or higher registration fees for noisy trucks or cars; if so, what were the main findings of this feasibility study and what is the government's reaction to them; if not, will the Minister request officers of his Department to undertake such a feasibility study and if so, when.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aviation has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) The House of Representatives Select Committee on Aircraft Noise in its Report published in 1970 recommended that consideration be given to a variable airport charge related to the noise level of each aircraft. The Department of Aviation presented a submission on this matter to the later enquiry on the same subject, started in 1982, by the House of Representatives Select Committee on Aircraft Noise. Their Report tabled in November 1985 did not make any recommendations concerning noise related landing charges.

The submission by the Department concluded that the imposition of a noise charge for the purpose of reducing aircraft noise would prove of little benefit. The reasons for introducing noise charges in European countries are not generally applicable to Australian conditions. In view of the conclusions of the submission and the lack of any recommendation by the Committee the Government does not intend to pursue this matter any further.

No specific feasibility study has been conducted relating to the higher registration fees for noisy trucks or cars. However a report is currently being prepared for the Australian Environment Council and the Australian Transport Advisory Council on control of motor vehicle noise. The report is expected to take into account a number of non-vehicle measures including fiscal incentives. The report is expected to be finalised in 1988.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Territories, upon notice, on 17 March 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Can the Minister for Territories provide advice concerning the proposed construction of a 200-bedroom hotel on Cocos (Keeling) Islands.
(2) Has approval been given for the construction of such a hotel.
(3) Who is proposing to develop this facility.

(4) Is it anticipated that airport facilities on Cocos will require upgrading to enable air access for tourists visiting the Islands, and using the proposed facilities; if so, have proposals for the upgrading of the airstrip, and airport been considered and/or approved.
(5) Who is to bear the cost of these improvements.
(6) Will the Commonwealth pay for any of the airport upgrading; if so, what proportion of the cost will it meet.
(7) Will the hotel developer meet any of the costs of upgrading airport facilities; if so, what proportion of the costs will the developer meet.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (7) No firm proposal for construction has been put to the Commonwealth. Discussions are being held with a Developer who has proposed a Chalet Style Resort. The proposal under consideration was submitted by Christmas and Cocos Island Tours Pty Ltd, a Perth based company, and was one of three proposals received in response to the Cocos (Keeling) Islands Council's call for expressions of interest in tourism.
