ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 6 May 1987 (Hansard, page 2395) Senator Archer asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Transport, a question concerning shipping services between Tasmania and the mainland. I pointed out at that time that I would seek further information so as to provide Senator Archer with a more concise and precise answer. The Minister for Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Government is aware of the impact that disruption in Bass Strait shipping services has on the Tasmanian economy, and is very concerned about this matter.

The Minister for Transport this week spoke with Mr Foster of the Tasmanian Farmers and Graziers Association who outlined the gravity of the situation which has arisen as a result of industrial disruption at Webb Dock. The Minister has passed on this information to the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations.
The Government is most concerned at what happened at Webb Dock. Disputes of this nature undermine our reputation as a reliable trading partner and threaten the employment of other Australian workers.

In respect of other industrial problems which have arisen in recent months, discussions have been held between the Government, the ACTU and the unions concerned. The ACTU has been using its good offices to help bring about settlements of these problems.

The ACTU and the unions involved in shipping services to and from Tasmania recognise the importance of these services, and have a general policy of, as far as practicable, exempting Tasmania from industrial disputes.

The recent dispute at Webb Dock in Melbourne has been settled and the terminal resumed operations on 8 May 1987. During the dispute other shipping operators maintained their Bass Strait services and ANL has rearranged its schedules to clear backlogs of cargo as soon as possible.

This Government's commitment to improving the efficiency and industrial relations of our shipping and waterfront industries is well known. It has taken major initiatives to achieve these objectives through the Waterfront Strategy and the package developed through the Maritime Industry Development Committee.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 11 November 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many seismic stations are there currently in Australia involved with the detection of nuclear explosions and where are they situated.
(2) What is the Australian agency involved in running these stations and which are the co-operating agencies in the United States and any other countries involved.

(3) If one of the co-operating agencies in the United States is the US Coast and Geodetic Survey, does overall control of the network remain the responsibility of the US Defence Advanced Research Projects Agency.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Seismic stations most commonly used at present are:
(a) the Alice Springs Seismic Array (Joint Geological and Geophysical Research Station), Alice Springs, Northern Territory;
(b) the Warramunga Seismic Array, near Tennant Creek, Northern Territory;
(c) the World Wide Standard Seismograph (WWSS) and the Abbreviated Seismic Research Observatory at Charters Towers, Queensland;
(d) the Seismic Research Observatory (SRO) at Narrogin, Western Australia; and
(e) the Mawson seismographic station, Mawson, Antarctica.
There are a number of other seismic stations in Australia capable of detecting nuclear explosions which are infrequently used for this purpose.
(2) The agencies involved with the operation of the stations referred to in (1)-(e) are as follows:
(a) the Bureau of Mineral Resources, Geology and Geophysics (BMR) and the US Air Force;
(b) the Australian National University and the National Environmental Research Council (UK);
(c) the University of Queensland; the BMR and the US Geological Survey (USGS) US Department of the Interior;
(d) the BMR and the USGS;
(e) the BMR and the Antarctic Division of the Department of Science.
All the infrequently used stations referred to in (1) above are operated solely by Australian agencies.
(3) Not applicable-see answer to (2) above.

The authority responsible for analysing data produced by seismic stations in Australia, with a view to monitoring nuclear explosions, is the Australian Seismological Centre in Canberra which is part of the BMR and not responsible to any foreign agency.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 23 February:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Government aware of recent press reports that the United States Institute of Policy Studies (IPS) has received documents from the US Defense Department which state that Britain, Australia and the United States carried out secret exercises at least three years ago to improve their ability to handle accidents or terrorist threats involving nuclear weapons.
(2) What was the purpose of these exercises, and what scenarios were exercised.
(3) What role did Australia play in these accidents.

(4) The documents received by IPS revealed that Australia agreed ``to improve radiological monitoring and diagnostic capabilities'' for detecting a nuclear weapons accident and what action has Australia taken to meet this commitment.
(5) What action would the US Nuclear Emergency Search Team based in the Pacific take in the event of (i) a nuclear weapons accident, and (ii) a nuclear reactor accident, in an Australian port.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) (3) and (4) The press reports are misleading. I am advised that the document on which they are based makes one brief mention of Australia and this refers to the participation by US officers from the US Armed Forces Radiobiological Research Unit in a 1984 seminar run by the Australian Department of Defence on the medical effects of nuclear, biological and chemical warfare. The officers attended under the auspices of the multilateral defence science Technical Co-operation Program, and gave a short presentation on the medical effects of nuclear weapons accidents. Such seminars are not related to any particular scenario or contingency, but rather reflect broad Australian interest in maintaining some expertise in the medical effects of a variety of weapons types.
Australia has not participated in combined nuclear weapons exercises, nor have any such exercises been proposed.
Australia has not entered any agreement to improve its radiological monitoring and diagnostic capabilities for detecting a nuclear weapons accident.

(5) The US Nuclear Emergency Search Team is a US Department of Energy organisation, stationed in the United States. It is a specialised team designed to search for nuclear devices or materials in a variety of scenarios.

In the unlikely event of a nuclear reactor or nuclear weapon accident in an Australian port, Australia could request US assistance in responding to the accident. The nature of any assistance would depend on the circumstances of the accident.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 23 March 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister for Resources and Energy aware that as a consequence of their obligation to adhere to Federal Government policy a major Australian oil re- finer incurred extraordinary stock losses of $33.7m after tax in 1986.

(2) Did this occur as a result of the falling off in price of Australian crude oil brought about by the Government's decision to continue the import parity pricing system at a time when international oil prices had collapsed.
(3) What are the responsibilities of the Federal Government to fully investigate the economic implications of policy decisions made by the Government for Australian companies.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) and (3) The import parity pricing policy for Australian crude oil reflects the long established principle that the price of Australian crude oils sold under the Crude Oil Allocation Scheme are priced at the cost of their replacement with imported crude oil.

Following the substantial fall in world oil prices early in 1986 and the consequent significant reduction in import parity prices for Australian crude oils from 1 March 1986, the Government gave consideration to the implications of the pricing decision for the holdings by Australian refiners of high cost crude oil and refined petroleum products.

The Government decided to compensate refiners for their losses on liftings of domestic crude oil in February 1986 and an amount of $124.8 million was paid to the companies under the Oil Companies (Stock Loss Reimbursement) Act 1986. In addition, commencing in April 1986 the Prices Surveillance Authority provided refiners with compensation for their other losses by means of three surcharges (totalling 1.95 cents/litre) on the wholesale price of notifiable petroleum products.

The surcharges remained in place until 13 February 1987. While the Prices Surveillance Authority does not reveal the calculations on which its decision to remove the surcharges was based, it is understood that the Prices Surveillance Authority was satisfied that the refiners had recovered the stock losses incurred during 1986 and that continuation of the surcharges was therefore no longer appropriate.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 30 April 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Was the 1985-86 research program on `GPS Error Analysis' at the University of NSW, which was funded by the Defence Science and Technology Organisation, related to the NAVSTAR Global Positioning System; if so, was the research related to maximising the accuracy of NAVSTAR receivers.
(2) What military applications are envisaged for the NAVSTAR system, and for the University of N.S.W research program in particular.
(3) Was this research program initiated at the request of the United States Government. If not, how was it initiated.
(4) What other assistance is being provided by Australia to the development and implementation of the NAVSTAR system.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The program concerned was related to the NAVSTAR Global Positioning System (GPS). It sought to quantify the performance of GPS in the Australian region in order to develop procedures for competitive evaluation of GPS receivers from various sources for supply to the Australian Defence Force (ADF), but was not related to the receivers per se. The accuracy of location provided by a receiver is of course a primary consideration in the evaluation process.

(2) The ADF will use GPS for survey, navigation of air, sea and land platforms and this will increase the effectiveness of the ADF. Similar benefits could be expected by most military users. In the longer term the System could provide guidance for weapons acquired by the ADF if receivers can be made small enough. The precise timing of the GPS transmissions can provide synchronising signals for modern military communications systems. There is no direct military application of the University of NSW research, although it would underpin ADF use of the GPS as explained above.

(3) This program was not initiated at the request of the United States Government. The research program is one of the many initiated in academic institutions by the Australian Defence Science and Technology Organisation to support that Organisation's work for the ADF. The School of Surveying at the University of NSW was awarded the research contract concerned because it is a centre of expertise in the field of satellite navigation.

(4) The Smithfield TRANET Station in South Australia (also operated by the DSTO) is tracking the research and development satellites of the GPS. An ADF officer is attached to the GPS Project Office in the USA to assist in transferring GPS technology to Australia.
